Released details of the reopening plan
Comments:
Phase 1: Stabilization focusing on healing Hawai‘i by saving lives and flattening the curve in the community. Hawai‘i has transitioned through this phase by re-opening low-risk businesses in the last few weeks.
Phase 2: Re-opening Hawai‘i’s Kama‘āina Economy, where the state starts to re-open medium-risk businesses and activities, and later – re-opening high-risk businesses and activities.
Phase 3: Long-term recovery – where the state renews and rebuilds its economy through planning and policy discussions, incorporating transitional workforce modernization opportunities, supporting economic diversification initiatives, targeting the development of emerging industries, and advancing long-term resiliency planning. At this level, the state will focus on re-opening highest risk businesses and activities, while remaining cautious and adjusting Safe Practices as needed. This phase is expected to take much longer, since this phase covers the reshaping of Hawai‘i’s economy.
Phase 4:  Resilience

Statewide positivity rate for COVID-19 has now averaged 9.2% for the past 7 days, COVID hospitalizations are at a 6 week low, and  hospital bed and ICU bed availability is above 30%
$7.3 million investment from the U.S. Small Business Administration (SBA) for the Illinois Small Business Development Center (SBDC) program
lifted the ban related to worship services
$1.7 million from the federal Administration for Community Living to provide services to older adults and persons with disabilities who are disproportionally affected by the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic
1 million tests have been performed in Illinois
IDHS created 2 covid response programs
Comments:
A summer youth program for more than 2,000 at-risk youth
An Immigrant Family Support Project for more than 3,600 families who have been generally excluded from or ineligible for federal COVID-19 relief and unemployment insurance.

Title/Description: State is not ready to allow for hotels to operate and reopen ballrooms at half-capacity
$275 million in funding for the Low-Income Home Energy Assistance Program and Community Service Block Grant Programs
Comments: Additional $90 million was allocated via the CARES act

Title/Description: Limit gatherings.
Comments: Non-essential gatherings be limited to 250 people

Title/Description: School absence.
Comments: Schools provide a 20-day waiver of the required 180 days of instructions

Title/Description: Nursing home and chilcare restrictions.
Comments: Nursing homes restrict and screen visitors, and daycare facilities implement social distancing practices.

Title/Description: Prison visitations restrictions.
Comments: Indiana Department of Corrections suspended visitation at all facilities

Title/Description: Meal services restrictions.
Comments: Suspending congregate meals and services and arrange for home delivery

Title/Description: Work limitaions.
Comments: Encouraging businesses to utilize telework policies (if available).

Title/Description: Hossier assistance measures.
Comments: All state agencies are evaluating rules and regulations that should be suspended or modified to assist Hoosiers during this public emergency.

Title/Description: Family Social Services Administration assistance.
Comments: Family Social Services Administration has asked federal officials to approve a request to temporarily waive the renewal process for Hoosiers who need SNAP or TANF benefits

Title/Description: Indiana Department of Education education and meal assistance.
Comments: Indiana Department of Education to discuss solutions regarding student assessments and meals for children.

Title/Description: Even restrictions.
Comments: Canceling or postponing in-person events of more than 50 people during the next eight weeks.

Title/Description: School closures.
Comments: 273 public school districts are closed, using e-learning days, or on spring break and have announced a future closure.

Title/Description: Outing closures.
Comments: Bars, nightclubs and restaurants are required to close to in-person patrons

Title/Description: Medical restrictions
Comments: Hospitals and ambulatory surgical centers should cancel and/or postpone elective and non-urgent surgical procedures immediately

Title/Description: Emergency Operations Center Change
Comments: The state’s Emergency Operations Center has been raised to a Level 1 status

Title/Description: Remote work
Comments: State employees maximize use of remote work and meet virtually. Non-essential in-person meetings limited to 10 persons or less.

Title/Description: Elderly recommendeation
Comments: State employees over the age of 60 with underlying health conditions are advised to work from home

Title/Description: Ease of unemployment restrictions.
Comments: The Department of Workforce Development (DWD) suspended rules requiring certain unemployment insurance claimants to physically appear at a Work

Title/Description: Event change
Comments: The Indiana Economic Development Corporation postpones inaugural Indiana Global Economic Summit, scheduled for April 26-28.

Title/Description: Child care and Elderly implementations
Comments: Communities are encouraged to work together to provide child care options and delivery services for senior citizens.

Title/Description: Executive order: National Guard implemented
Comments: Activating the national guard to support the COVID-19 response.

Title/Description: COVID-19 testing
Comments: Partnership with Eli Lilly and Company, with support from the Food and Drug Administration, to accelerate testing in Indiana for COVID-19.

Title/Description: Request for Economic Injury Disaster Loan assistance.
Comments: U.S. Small Business Administration issue an Economic Injury Disaster Loan declaration to support small businesses impacted by the coronavirus outbreak in Indiana.

Title/Description: School closures.
Comments: All Indiana public schools are now closed and are using alternative learning options like e-learning.

Title/Description: Extension of state of emergency
Comments: Extended the current state of emergency for an additional 30 days.

Title/Description: School closures.
Comments: Ordered all K-12 school to remain closed until May 1. Private schools are also ordered closed.

Title/Description: U.S. Department of Education cancel requirements for assessments.
Comments: Coordinated with the U.S. Department of Education to receive federal waivers needed to cancel the requirements for accountability, chronic absenteeism and state-mandated assessments.

Title/Description: State income tax data change.
Comments: Aligned with the federal government for the collection date of state income tax.

Title/Description: Stop of capital projects.
Comments: Halted several capital projects that would have used $300 million from the state’s reserves.

Title/Description: Prohibits utility cut off.
Comments: Prohibited utilities from cutting off services

Title/Description: Prohibits evictions.
Comments: Prohibited evictions from residential homes and communities

Title/Description: Request for state Insurance Commissioner for COVID-19 testing costs.
Comments: Ordered the state Insurance Commissioner to request health insurers to cover COVID-19 testing costs and to not increase prices or coverage costs for medical care for COVID-19.

Title/Description: Limit DMV transactions.
Comments: Ordered the DMV to limit the number of in-branch transactions.

Title/Description: Ease health professional licensure.
Comments: Eased licensure requirements for health care professionals and promoted tele-health support.

Title/Description: Ease veteran qualifications.
Comments: Relaxed requirements for veterans to qualify for awards under the Military Relief Fund.

Title/Description: Primary election date change
Comments: May 5th to June 2nd.

Title/Description: Executive Order.
Comments: Requiring residents to stay at home, unless they are engaging in essential activities including: Activities for health and safety, necessary supplies and services, outdoor activity, certain types of essential work, and taking care of others

Title/Description: Executive Order.
Comments: Ceases in person dining.

Title/Description: Executive Order
Comments: Allowing restaurants that have a liquor permit to conduct the sale of alcohol for carryout/delivery.

Title/Description: Open schools for childcare services.
Comments: The Indiana State Department of Education (DOE) and Family and Social Services Administration (FSSA) have teamed to encourage school corporations in Indiana to open schools on a limited basis to provide childcare services for emergency workers.

Title/Description: Community Development Block Grant funds redirected
Comments: Office of Community and Rural Affairs announced Community Development Block Grant funds may be redirected to assist with COVID-19 needs based on guidance from the United States Housing and Urban Development

Title/Description: The Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) approved Indiana’s request for a Section 1135 Medicaid waiver.
Comments: The approved waiver enables Indiana to provide flexibilities in Medicaid provider screening and enrollment, forgo certain pre-admission screening and annual resident review assessments, lift prior authorization requirements, allow for reimbursement facility services in alternative settings, and extend fair hearing and appeals timelines.

Title/Description: Incarcerated individuals at the Miami Correctional Facility are producing face masks, personal protection gowns, face shields and hand sanitizer.
Executive Order
Comments: Removes all regulatory barriers to prepare for surge capacity and allow for authorized medical professionals to practice, including students and those who have retired.

Title/Description: Sent a letter to issue disaster relief for Indiana
Executive Order.
Comments: Extending the carry-out only order for restaurants and bars through April 6th.

Title/Description: Executive Order.
Comments: Lottery winners will be given an additional 60 days to claim prizes

Title/Description: Executive Order.
Comments: Indian Horse Racing Rules will be suspended

Title/Description: Executive Order.
Comments: The Alumni Trustee Election for Indiana University will be postponed

Title/Description: Executive Order.
Comments: Concerning remote education for K-12 school for the remainder of the year, graduation requirements, and the extension of the renewal/expiration date of teacher’s licenses.

Title/Description: Executive Order.
Comments: Extending the public health emergency and stay-at-home order through April 20.

Title/Description: Essential businesses are being directed to limit their store hours and limit the number of patrons in stores
Comments: To comply with social distancing, as well as being encouraged to have specific hours for at-risk and elderly patrons.

Title/Description: All gatherings, public or private, of 10 or more people will continue to be prohibited.
Campgrounds are closed, including at state parks.
Comments: People living in RVs with no other place to go can stay there.

Title/Description: The sale of firearms and ammunition will not be restricted.
People should not be crossing state lines for pleasure or leisure.
Comments: Stated in a press conference. The state will make more stringent policies if needed.

Title/Description: Executive Order.
Comments: Allowing retired healthcare workers to receive temporary licenses to practice in the state, allow home health agencies to accept written orders for home health services, and other provisions.

Title/Description: Cautioned citizens not to have large Easter gatherings
The state has exhausted its federal stockpile of personal protective equipment
There were 133,600 unemployment claims to date
There had been 214 complaints and 80 citations to businesses not following his essential business order.
Guidance for places of worship.
Executive Order.
Comments: To waive education requirements that cannot be met due to school buildings being closed.

Title/Description: the Indiana Economic Relief and Recovery Team will plan, administer and account for relief funds
Comments: for state and local government, businesses and individuals

Title/Description: 2.4 billion from the U.S. Treasury Coronavirus Relief Fund
Comments: will be used towards costs the state incurred from March-December 2020

Title/Description: $500 million from the CARES Act will be allocated to K-12 and higher education programs
12,000 Indianans have joined the volunteer health care registry
the Indiana Economic Development Corporation (IEDC) has secured commitments
Comments: for more than 2.6 million pieces of PPE, with more than 1.9 million items being made by 15 Indiana manufacturers.

Title/Description: Indiana businesses across the state are answering the call to support the COVID-19 response effort
Comments: The state’s manufacturers are leveraging their resources, supply chains and Hoosier workers to produce personal protection equipment (PPE) for health care providers

Title/Description: The Governor will revisit the state’s stay-at-home order on Friday, April 17th and adjust as necessary.
Indicated that models are demonstrating an upcoming surge of cases
easing of restrictions and re-opening of certain sectors in Indiana will not happen all at once but will happen in waves.
if a healthcare worker or a first responder has someone symptomatic in their home, they can have those people tested at ISDH drive-thru testing centers.
The Governor would be making decisions end the stay-at-home order based on what is occurring throughout the state and region.
The Governor has joined a partnership with 6 other states in the region (Michigan, Ohio, Wisconsin, Minnesota, Illinois, and Kentucky) to develop a plan for reopening the region economy.
The stay-at-home order would be extended to May 1st.
hospitals should conduct medically necessary procedures
Comments: As long as sufficient personal protective equipment (PPE), staff and other supplies are available for the COVID-19 response, hospitals should conduct medically necessary procedures, such as those determining cancer diagnosis and cardiac issues, respiratory procedures, and procedures to reduce significant pain or symptoms making quality of life unacceptable.Any restrictions involving medical procedures will be evaluated every seven days for appropriate and timely modifications that could be implemented.

Title/Description: Permitted outdoor activity as described in the executive order
Comments: includes yard work, gardening, planting and landscaping at residential, commercial and industrial properties and farms.

Title/Description: Nurseries and garden centers may be open for business
Comments: They must limit the number of customers in their facility at any given time to achieve the Centers for Disease Control’s required social distancing, limit their hours of operation and consider implementing separate operating hours for the elderly and other vulnerable customers, and comply with the social distancing, sanitation and other mitigation measure to protect its employees and the public.

Title/Description: Pet grooming at a pet salon, store or mobile unit is permitted.
eased restrictions on hospitals from performing elective surgeries.
the state will send a “testing strike team” to Tama County
Comments: to help control an outbreak of COVID-19 at a long-term care facility.

Title/Description: The U.S. Food and Drug Administration authorized home collection tests
will be available in most states via doctor’s order in the coming weeks.
The state has purchased 50,000 swabs for use in testing
Comments: Eli Lilly and Co. donated 32,000, the Federal Emergency Management Agency provided 20,000 and 4,000 have been donated.

Title/Description: The state is partnering with the Indiana University Richard M. Fairbanks School of Public Health
Comments: Conducting a study regarding antibodies showing past COVID-19 infection. Participants will be chosen from a list of tax filers and their dependents.

Title/Description: Executive Order
Comments: Extending the deadline for business personal property tax returns.

Title/Description: Executive Order
Comments: Suspending the 5-year limitation on business reinstatement and the requirements for a business to submit a certificate of clearance when applying, allowing them to qualify for seeking federal assistance programs.

Title/Description: Executive Order
Comments: Allowing corporations registered in Indiana to hold remote board meetings via notification to its shareholders.

Title/Description: Executive Order
Comments: Expediting unemployment insurance claims adjudication

Title/Description: not considering extending the state’s stay at home order until the end of May.
Comments: He said he is focusing on May 1 and will continue to operate in two and three-week increments.

Title/Description: Executive Order
Comments: To allow health care providers and facilities to resume elective medical procedures provided they have sufficient quantities of Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) and consult the best practices and recommendations developed by their medical associations or industries.

Title/Description: Executive Order
Comments: To speed up the review of unemployment insurance claim appeals during the fight against COVID-19.

Title/Description: Indiana Economic Development Corporation (IEDC) has secured commitments for more than 6.3 million pieces of personal protective equipment (PPE).
Comments: Of these, more than 2.9 million items, including face masks, face shields, gloves, gowns, goggles and bottles of hand sanitizer, are being made and sourced by 18 Indiana manufacturers.

Title/Description: the Family and Social Services Administration has launched a new website, BeWellIndiana.org,
Comments: will provide free mental health resources that have been vetted by experts. The site is designed to help with the increase in anxiety, depression and other mental health issues caused by the pandemic, including both first-time issues as well as pre-existing mental health concerns.

Title/Description: twelve safe recovery sites have been established
Comments: to help people who are recovering from COVID-19 and also experiencing homelessness.

Title/Description: Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP):
Comments: 400,000 Indiana children will receive additional benefits on their existing SNAP cards as part of SNAP-Pandemic EBT benefits, or will receive cards for the first time.

Title/Description: Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP):
Comments: In mid-May, grocery delivery will be available for those receiving SNAP benefits.

Title/Description: Essential workers seeking childcare options should contact Bright Futures Indiana.
OptumServe Health Services would be opening sites across Indiana in the next seven days
Comments: To begin large-scale testing.

Title/Description: 3,700 people have signed up for a study conducted by the state and Indiana University public health researchers.
Comments: The study will test 5,000 to 7,000 randomly chosen people in four phases over the next year.

Title/Description: A strike team tested all employees at a Tyson plant in Cass County
Comments: where there was an outbreak of the coronavirus.

Title/Description: the state is partnering with Maximus to centralize contact tracing and investigations for Indianans who test positive for COVID-19.
Kroger will launch free drive-thru testing in Fort Wayne on Thursday and plans to open a site in Marion County.
the state has acquired a critical care decontamination system that will allow health care providers to conserve N95 masks
Comments: by sending them off to be professionally decontaminated. The masks can be decontaminated up to 20 times.

Title/Description: The Health Commissioner announced that a centralized contact tracing system will begin May 11.
Comments: All positive patients and close contacts will be asked to contact a call center. The center will complete initial phone interviews. If a person does not contact the center, the center will contact them. The center will also send daily texts or emails to monitor a person’s symptoms.

Title/Description: A person who is out of work due to COVID-19 must return to work if called back to remain eligible for benefits.
Comments: Not returning could be considered a “refusal to work” and potentially disqualify claimants. If the person returns to work but works a reduced number of hours, they can still file for partial benefits. Further, the commissioner clarified that the workforce department does not regulate workplaces, but that it will evaluate on a case by case basis every claim that comes in. If a person claims the employer’s place is unfit, the department will consider that as part of a refusal to work determination.

Title/Description: The number of hospitalized COVID-19 patients statewide has decreased for 14 days.
The state retains its surge capacity for critical care beds and ventilators.
The state retains its ability to test all individuals who are COVID-19 symptomatic as well as health care workers, first responders, and frontline employees.
Health officials have systems in place to contact all individuals who test positive for COVID-19 and expand contact tracing.
The Indiana Retired Teachers Association set up a hotline to assist students and parents each weekday from 1-5 p.m.
Indiana is working closely with counties in Kentucky regarding the state’s reopening procedures.
the state has received an initial shipment of Remdesivir, shipped to a state hotspot.
Comments: Remdesivir is an antiviral medication that has received clearance from the Food and Drug Administration to be used with COVID-19 patients.

Title/Description: The Office of Management and Budget stated that Indiana missed its revenue projections by 6 percent ($70 million).
Comments: Which offset the revenues from the previous eight months.

Title/Description: Indiana has made $119 million in payments to 57,000 claimants through the state’s Pandemic Unemployment Assistance program
Executive Order
Comments: Encourages the hiring of poll workers by prohibiting the that the stipend poll workers receive from qualifying as deductible income for those receiving unemployment benefits

Title/Description: Executive Order
Comments: The extension of Waiver of Late Fees and Penalties by the Bureau of Motor Vehicles

Title/Description: Executive Order
Comments: The extension of certain tax deadlines

Title/Description: The Governor's daily press briefings on COVID-19 would be now occurring Monday, Wednesday, and Fridays.
Comments: Additionally, his team announced that contact tracing is now occurring on a larger scale in the state.

Title/Description: There have been over 1,400 compliance complaints submitted about businesses across the state.
Comments: A total of 138 verbal warnings have been issued to businesses, and most businesses have complied after verbal warning. Only one cease and desist order has had to be issued in the state.

Title/Description: The Indiana State Health Department Commissioner announced that 2.3 million pieces of PPE are being delivered to hospitals.
Comments: Local health departments are receiving 1.3 million pieces of PPE.

Title/Description: The Governor announced that they had received two shipments of Remdesivir.
Comments: One shipment was delivered to a hotspot in northern Indiana. The second was sent to the state health department. Indiana will start receiving weekly shipments of the antiviral drug.

Title/Description: The Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) approved Indiana’s second request for a Medicaid 1135 waiver.
Comments: The waiver allows Indiana to reimburse for Home and Community-Based Services (HCBS) in additional settings

Title/Description: Indiana has procured commitments for more than 16 million pieces of PPE.
Comments: More than 12 million pieces have already been delivered and 20,000 orders have been received through the PPE Marketplace. 10,000 orders have been shipped, and 12,000 orders are anticipated to go out next week.

Title/Description: The Secretary of State office announced it will supply all Indiana county election offices with PPE.
Comments: The Indiana National Guard will handle distribution.

Title/Description: The Indiana Department of Workforce Development Commissioner said Indiana has paid out more than $1.4 million in unemployment insurance payments since March.
The Governor and the Indiana Family and Social Services Administration announced the state will fund a nearly $1 million distribution of the opioid reversal agent naloxone.
Indiana will begin stage 3 of its “Back on Track” plan two days ahead of schedule.
Comments: Stage 3 was originally slated to begin the day before Memorial Day. The following activities may open: community pools, gyms, playgrounds, campgrounds and basketball courts (and similar facilities). Mall common areas and movie theaters will be able to open at 50% capacity, and retail stores can up capacity to 75%.

Title/Description: Executive Order
Comments: Moving the state into Phase 3 of reopening.

Title/Description: The Indiana Department of Homeland Security stated the agency’s is continuing its code enforcement arm
Comments: Visits businesses every day to monitor safety codes and occupancy rates.

Title/Description: Over 20,000 bundles of personal protective equipment have been shipped to businesses.
Comments: The Indiana Economic Development Corporation stated that over 20,000 bundles of personal protective equipment have been shipped to businesses through the IEDC’s marketplace. Another 15,000 are set to go out.

Title/Description: The second phase of the IU School of Health Fairbanks research study will begin the following week.
Comments: The study found that the current statewide population prevalence rate is 2.8%, and 44.8% of those who tested positive were asymptomatic.

Title/Description: 26% of all Medicaid mental health services from March-April of this year were provided through telehealth.
Comments: The Family and Social Services Administration Secretary said 26% of all Medicaid mental health services from March-April of this year were provided through telehealth, as compared to 6% from March-April of last year.

Title/Description: $5 billion has been awarded to Indiana from the federal government.
Comments: The Director of the Office of Budget & Management said $5 billion has been awarded to Indiana from the federal government. About $2.4 billion is for coronavirus relief.

Title/Description: The Governor is working to finalize details on what the fall semester will look like for K-12 students.
Comments: The Governor announced that he is currently working with local schools and the Indiana Department of Education (IDOE) to finalize details on what the fall semester will look like for K-12 students and that schools will likely reopen in the fall.

Title/Description: Several new economic recovery initiatives designed to bolster critical relief efforts while encouraging long-term planning and investments to stimulate Indiana’s economy well into the future.
Comments: Through these initiatives, the state will allocate nearly $44 million to provide support and resources including approximately $37 million in direct funding through grants and investments to small businesses and manufacturers.

Title/Description: Executive Order 20-29
Comments: To lift restrictions on local declarations of emergency that had been instituted as a part of the stay at home and back on track orders pertaining to COVID-19. This order allows local governments to place more stringent travel restrictions than the state has in place.

Title/Description: The second phase of the Fairbanks study has started.
The Indiana State Department of Health announced PPE supply chains for hospitals and suppliers have opened up.
Comments: Has allowed Indiana to build its own inventory in case of a second wave of the virus in the fall.

Title/Description: Indiana received $17 million in additional funding through the CARES Act for the Low Income Home Energy Assistance Program.
50 million in federal funding is being provided through the CARES Act to help Indianans get jobs.
Comments: The funding will provide free access to online courses and training and will also create an online network that can connect people with career coaches. The Employer Training Grant will also be expanded, with a portion of funds dedicated to supporting minority, women and veteran-owned businesses.

Title/Description: The state to enter Stage 4 of reopening, which is set to begin June 14.
Comments: Officials are still discussing whether to extend the moratorium on evictions.

Title/Description: Launching a lab testing network to increase daily testing capacity.
Comments: The Indiana Department of Health announced that the state has partnered with Eli Lilly and the Indiana Hospital Association. The network will include 10 labs across the state. The network will leverage the state’s “buying power” to better compete for testing supplies.

Title/Description: OptumServe testing sites will be open to anyone regardless of whether they are high-risk or symptomatic.
Comments: Announced by the Indiana State Department of Health.

Title/Description: The State Office of Management and Budget predicted that the state would be $2 billion behind its revenue forecast due to COVID-19 impacts.
The state COVID-19 briefings will be reduced only once per week.
A 183 million increase in K-12 spending and Indiana school corporations will get an additional $192 million out of the federal CARES Act.
Comments: $61 million from the governor’s emergency fund will help with eLearning.

Title/Description: Indiana PK-12 schools and higher education institutions can now apply for a needs-based, competitive $61.6 million grant program.
Comments: Providing funding to improve remote learning.

Title/Description: A new rental assistance program will provide up to $500 a month per household for those who are unable to pay rent due to a COVID-19 related job loss.
Comments: Announced by the Indiana Housing and Community Development Authority Executive Director. Households can qualify for up to four months of assistance, or $2,000. An estimated 12,000 household renters will be served.

Title/Description: The state will modify the Back On Track Indiana plan through at least July 17.
Comments: Social gatherings following the CDC’s social distancing guidelines will be limited to up to 250 people. This limit applies to wedding receptions, parties, and other events where people are in close physical contact for extended periods of time, particularly indoors.

Title/Description: The state will modify the Back On Track Indiana plan through at least July 17.
Comments: Dining room food service may continue operations at up to 75 percent capacity as long as social distancing is observed. Bar seating in restaurants may continue operations at 50 percent capacity. Bars and nightclubs may continue operations open at 50 percent capacity as long as they adhere to social distancing guidelines.

Title/Description: The state will modify the Back On Track Indiana plan through at least July 17.
Comments: Cultural, entertainment, and tourism sites may continue operations open at 50 percent capacity.

Title/Description: The state will modify the Back On Track Indiana plan through at least July 17.
Comments: Movie theaters, bowling alleys, and similar facilities may continue operations open at 50 percent capacity.

Title/Description: The state will modify the Back On Track Indiana plan through at least July 17.
Comments: Amusement parks, water parks and similar facilities may continue operations open at 50 percent capacity. Reservations are encouraged to limit the number of customers at any one time.

Title/Description: The state will modify the Back On Track Indiana plan through at least July 17.
Comments: Raceways may continue operations open at 50 percent grandstand capacity.

Title/Description: Cruise ship quarantined
School closures.
Comments: Iowa schools close for four weeks.

Title/Description: Work assistance.
Comments: Various forms of assistance to workers and employers in the face of potential COVID-19 layoffs or furloughs.

Title/Description: Medicaid appropriations
Comments: Supplemental appropriations for Medicaid ($88.98 million).

Title/Description: Health program appropriations
Comments: Supplemental appropriations other health programs ($1.8 million).

Title/Description: Hygienic Lab approriations
Comments: Supplemental appropriations for state hygienic lab ($525,000).

Title/Description: Limits standing appropriations
Comments: Limits some standing appropriations (non-public school transportation, instructional support, AEA funding).

Title/Description: Review FY 2020 aprropriations
Comments: Requires the Department of Management and the Legislative Service Agency to review FY 2020 appropriations and to make appropriations for the first two months of FY 2021.

Title/Description: Economic Emergency Fund appropriations.
Comments: Emergency appropriations from the Economic Emergency Fund of up to 10% to the DOM for purposes approved by the Governor, through August 31.

Title/Description: Waive school instruction.
Comments: Authorizes the Governor to waive school instructional time requirements for schools that close due to COVID-19.

Title/Description: Restaurant and bar closure.
Comments: State of public health disaster emergency closes all restaurants and bars to the public until March 31, excluding take-out and drive thru options.

Title/Description: Physician assistant role expansion.
Comments: Expands the roles of physician assistants in Iowa

Title/Description: Additional state public health emergency declaration provisions
Comments: Temporarily suspends penalties and interest related to collection of property taxes until the end of this proclamation.

Title/Description: Additional state public health emergency declaration provisions
Comments: Temporarily suspends some evictions under the Iowa Uniform Residential Landlord and Tenant Act or the Manufactured Home Communities or Mobile Home Parks Residential Landlord and Tenant Act in certain circumstances.

Title/Description: Additional state public health emergency declaration provisions
Comments: Extends expiration deadline for a permit to carry and a permit to acquire a firearm and additional measures.

Title/Description: Additional state public health emergency declaration provisions
Comments: Permits the sale of carry-out, delivery, drive-thru alcohol for unopened bottles of alcohol for bars and restaurants and suspends some fees.

Title/Description: Additional state public health emergency declaration provisions
Comments: Permits public meetings or hearings by electronic means to improve the functions of government while maintaining social distancing practices.

Title/Description: Additional state public health emergency declaration provisions
Comments: Suspends certain regulations to ease the transportation of agricultural supplies and commodities, food, medical supplies, cleaning products, and other household goods on all highways in Iowa.

Title/Description: Additional state public health emergency declaration provisions
Comments: The proclamation also allows related state agencies to implement the state’s public health emergency plan.

Title/Description: U.S. Small Business Administration will issue an Economic Injury Disaster Loan declaration for Iowa.
New proclamation continuing the State Public Health Emergency Declaration.
Comments: The closure of salons, medical spas, barbershops, tattoo establishments, tanning facilities, massage therapy establishments, and swimming pools until March 31.

Title/Description: New proclamation continuing the State Public Health Emergency Declaration.
Comments: Suspends all foreclosures on residential, commercial, and agricultural real property.

Title/Description: New proclamation continuing the State Public Health Emergency Declaration.
Comments: Professional licensing relief.

Title/Description: First quarter unemployment tax payments delayed.
Comments: first quarter unemployment tax payments that are due April 30th will be delayed till the end of the 2nd quarter, July 31, 2020. Eligible employers include those employers with 50 or fewer employees.

Title/Description: President Trump approved request for a Presidential Major Disaster Declaration for COVID-19.
Comments: notification that President Trump has approved her request for a Presidential Major Disaster Declaration for COVID-19, removing a $5 million cap on federal funds as well as making available the Community Disaster Loan program.

Title/Description: The Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) approve Iowa's request for Section 1135 Medicaid waiver.
Comments: The Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) approved Iowa’s request for a Section 1135 Medicaid waiver. The approved waiver enables Iowa to forgo certain pre-admission screening and annual resident review assessments in its Medicaid program.

Title/Description: The Economic Development Authority created a COVID-19 Targeted Small Business Sole Operator Fund
Comments: To support small businesses with zero employees – designed to help women, individuals with minority status, service-connected disabled veterans and individuals with disabilities overcome hurdles to start or grow a small business.

Title/Description: New proclamation continuing the State Public Health Emergency Declaration
Comments: Suspending elective and nonessential medical and dental procedures, extending and expanding retail business closures, ordering health care facilities and nursing homes to engage in advanced health care screenings.

Title/Description: New proclamation continuing the state public health emergency declaration.
New proclamation continuing the State Public Health Emergency Declaration
Comments: The proclamation orders the closure of schools, waiving time requirements as long as school districts put in place a continuous learning plan until April 30th.

Title/Description: $44 million has been obligated to the State of Iowa for reimbursement of expenses related to the COVID-19 response.
New proclamation continuing the State Public Health Emergency Declaration, ordering additional closures and relaxing additional regulations.
the state is expanding a grant program for small businesses
Comments: after receiving thousands of applications requesting assistance

Title/Description: continuing theState Public Health Emergency Declaration and requiring additional protective measures in Region 6 (Northeastern Iowa).
Comments: Limiting social, community, recreational, leisure, and sporting gatherings in Region 6 to only people who live together in the same household

Title/Description: continuing theState Public Health Emergency Declaration and requiring additional protective measures in Region 6 (Northeastern Iowa).
Comments: Continuing to limit weddings, funerals, and other spiritual or religious gatherings to no more than 10 people

Title/Description: The Governor has released an updated dashboard on coronavirus.iowa.gov that will be updated daily to include comprehensive tracking of COVID-19 in Iowa.
Comments: The new dashboard includes cases, deaths, and tests conducted in each county. The state will also be providing demographic information that was not previously provided as well as Iowa’s epidemiological curve.

Title/Description: Plans to reopen Iowa through a “phased-in manner” following the guidelines issued by the president.
All school districts and nonpublic schools will be closed for the remainder of the school year.
Iowa meatpacking plants will stay open.
Test Iowa Initiative to expand testing capacity to limit the spread of COVID-19 in Iowa.
Comments: The state is partnering with Nomi Health and DOMO, which are part of a partnership that launched a similar initiative in the state of Utah.

Title/Description: A new proclamation continuing the State Public Health Emergency Declaration.
Comments: The proclamation permits health care providers to begin the process of resuming some elective surgeries and procedures through a phased approach, permits farmers markets to begin limited operations with appropriate public health precautions, and outlines other measures.

Title/Description: The Governor signed a new proclamation continuing the State Public Health Emergency Declaration until May 27, 2020.
Comments: The proclamation loosens social distancing measures in 77 Iowa counties effective Friday, May 1 and continues other restrictions until 11:50 p.m. on Friday, May 15, 2020. In the 77 counties, the proclamation permits restaurants, fitness centers, malls, libraries, racetracks, and certain other retail establishments to reopen in a limited fashion with public health measures in place.

Title/Description: The Governor, U.S. Senators Joni Ernst and Chuck Grassley, and Iowa Secretary of Agriculture Mike Naig wrote a letter to the Vice President asking for additional support from the administration for the state’s pork producers.

The Governor’s Iowa Workforce Development Agency, stated that during gradual reopen procedures if an employee refuses to return to work at a business that is opening again, that it would be considered as a “voluntary quit”
Comments: This would disqualify them from receiving unemployment benefits.

Title/Description: The state would clear its backlog of COVID-19 test results at the State Hygienic Laboratory by the end of Monday May 4th.
The Governor will travel to Washington to meet with President Donald Trump and Vice President Mike Pence to discuss Iowa’s response to the coronavirus pandemic.
A new proclamation continuing the Public Health Disaster Emergency.
Comments: The proclamation permits dental services to resume in compliance with guidelines adopted by the Iowa Dental Board, permits some additional businesses and establishments to reopen throughout Iowa in a limited fashion with appropriate public health measures in place, and provides additional regulatory relief to assist Iowans affected by this disaster.

Title/Description: The Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) approved Iowa’s second request for a Medicaid 1135 waiver.
Comments: The waiver allows Iowa to provide flexibilities in Medicaid provider screening and enrollment, forgo evaluation and assessment requirements for home and community-based services, and allow for reimbursement facility services in alternative settings.

Title/Description: The Governor will be following modified quarantine plan after learning a member of Vice President Mike Pence’s staff tested positive for the virus.
Comments: Gov. Reynolds says her temperature is being taken before she enters the building prior to her press briefing and she is being tested everyday.

Title/Description: The Governor will update her office’s public health guidelines in an updated proclamation.
Comments: According to information provided during her daily coronavirus briefing.

Title/Description: A new proclamation continuing the Public Health Disaster Emergency.
Comments: The proclamation permits salons, barbershops, and massage and tattoo establishments to reopen throughout Iowa in a limited fashion with appropriate public health measures in place. It also permits restaurants (but not bars), fitness centers, libraries, and racetracks to reopen in the 22 counties where they have remained closed. The proclamation continues the other ongoing closures and public health measures, including the prohibition on social, community, recreational, leisure, and sporting gatherings and events of more than 10 people, until 11:59 p.m. on May 27, 2020.

Title/Description: Test Iowa’s equipment has been validated and believes the state “has the capacity” to do 5,000 tests per day.
Comments: 3,000 via the Test Iowa program and another 2,000 through the state hygienic lab.

Title/Description: A new proclamation continuing the Public Health Disaster Emergency.
Comments: The proclamation permits summer school activities, including baseball and softball, to resume on June 1. Effective May 22, Movie theaters, zoos, aquariums, museums, and wedding reception venues will be permitted to reopen with appropriate public health measures in place. Swimming pools will also be permitted to reopen for lap swimming and swimming lessons.

Title/Description: On Thursday, May 28, bars and other alcohol-related establishments that have been limited to carryout and delivery will be permitted to reopen for indoor or outdoor seating.
Comments: These establishments will follow the same public health measures that restaurants have been implementing for the past several weeks.

Title/Description: The Governor signed a new proclamation continuing the Public Health Disaster Emergency until June 25, 2020.
Comments: The proclamation permits bars, wineries, breweries, distilleries, and social and fraternal clubs may reopen on May 28 with the same public health measures as restaurants in place. The proclamation also permits the reopening on June 1 of additional establishments, including outdoor performance venues, casinos, bowling alleys, amusement parks, skating rinks, skate parks, outdoor playgrounds.

Title/Description: June 1, speedways, and racetracks can open events to spectators.
Comments: Outdoor venues like grandstands and amphitheaters may hold performances. Casinos may reopen, along with amusement parks, bowling alleys, pool halls, and arcades. All must maintain 50% capacity while keeping social distancing and hygiene protocols going.

Title/Description: Confirmed cases of COVID-19 are trending toward the western side of the state.
150 National Guard soldiers are assisting with contact tracing.
The Governor and the Iowa Department of Education announced the state has received $26.2 million in federal relief.
Comments: To ensure education continues for students of all ages impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic.

Title/Description: The Governor will further expand access to COVID-19 testing with new sites opening this week.
Comments: Including one in Dallas County to better serve the Des Moines metro area, and four clinic sites in rural communities.

Title/Description: The Governor wrote a letter to Iowa Senators and the Secretary of the Department of Agriculture.
Comments: The Governor is asking for more federal support for state turkey producers due to disruptions occurring in the supply chain.

Title/Description: Executive Order.
Comments: Establishing the Governor’s Economic Recovery Advisory Board. The advisory board will focus on modernizing Iowa’s economy as well as education, health care, workforce and quality of life.

Title/Description: State of Emergency.
School closures.
Comments: K-12 school in Kansas close for the week of March 15.

Title/Description: Gathering limitaions
Comments: Banned all gatherings larger than 50 people, bringing the entire state in line with restrictions already announced in Wichita and Kansas City.

Title/Description: Working from home
Comments: Effective Monday, March 23, that state employees state home for two weeks on administrative leave to minimize additional risk of exposure to the virus.

Title/Description: School closures.
Comments: Closure of all K-12 schools in the state until the end of the school year.

Title/Description: Executive order: Gathering limitations
Comments: Limiting public gathering to no more than 50 people

Title/Description: Executive order: Suspend utility disconnections
Comments: Asked the Kansas Corporation Commission (KCC) to suspend utility disconnects until April 15.

Title/Description: Prohibit evictions and foreclosures
Comments: Executive Order #20-06 to temporarily prohibit evictions and foreclosures across the state.

Title/Description: Senate Bill for unemployment eligibility
Comments: Senate Bill 27 extends unemployment eligibility for workers who filed after January 1, 2020.

Title/Description: Senate Bill for education waiver expansion.
Comments: Senate Bill 142 expands education waiver authorities during disaster emergencies.

Title/Description: Senate Bill for judicial branch authority expansion.
Comments: Senate Bill 102 expands authorities of the judicial branch during disasters.

Title/Description: Disaster assistance loans from the U.S. Small Business Administration (SBA) to supplement small businesses.
Comments: Under the state’s disaster declaration Kansas has applied for, and expects to receive, disaster assistance loans from the U.S. Small Business Administration (SBA) to supplement small businesses.

Title/Description: Establish the Hospitality Industry Relief Emergency (HIRE) Fund
Comments: Allocation of 5 million of state funds to establish the Hospitality Industry Relief Emergency (HIRE) Fund to provide short-term, zero-interest loans for Kansas’ hospitality sector

Title/Description: Executive Order
Comments: Temporarily expanding telemedicine and addressing certain licensing requirements.

Title/Description: Executive Order
Comments: For conditional and temporary relief from certain motor carrier rules and regulations.

Title/Description: Executive Order
Comments: limiting mass gathering to 10 people.

Title/Description: Executive Order
Comments: Preventing all Kansas waste removal providers, trash and recycling, from cancelling or suspending commercial or residential waste or recycling removal services for Kansas residences and businesses as a result of nonpayment due to significant loss of income or increase in expenses resulting from the COVID-19 pandemic.

Title/Description: Executive Order
Comments: Extending tax filing deadlines to July 15, 2020, and waiving any interest and penalties for returns and payments made on or before July 15, 2020.

Title/Description: State Budget
Comments: Approves $65 million for Kansas coronavirus response.

Title/Description: Executive Order
Comments: Establishing the Kansas Essential Function Framework for the COVID-19 response.

Title/Description: The Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) approve Kansas’ request for a Section 1135 Medicaid waiver.
Comments: The approved waiver enables Kansas to provide flexibilities in Medicaid provider screening and enrollment, forgo certain pre-admission screening and annual resident review assessments, lift prior authorization requirements, and extend fair hearing and appeals timelines.

Title/Description: Executive Order
Comments: Instituting a temporary, statewide stay-home order until Sunday, April 19.

Title/Description: New executive order making changes to the state’s employment security law.
Comments: The waiting week requirement for unemployment benefits will be temporarily waived for all claimants.

Title/Description: New executive order making changes to the state’s employment security law.
Comments: The requirement that Kansans receiving unemployment benefits actively seek work each week will be temporarily waived for all claimants to allow Kansans to continue the necessary social distancing practices.

Title/Description: New executive order making changes to the state’s employment security law.
Comments: All Kansas employers, as required by the federal Department of Labor, will be required to notify separated employees if they qualify for unemployment insurance.

Title/Description: Executive Order.
Comments: Primarily brings religious institutions and religious and non-religious funerals in line with the a previous order that limited public gatherings to 10 or fewer people.

Title/Description: Legal action against members of the Legislative Coordinating Council (LCC).
Comments: Over its revocation of an executive order she issued that limited mass gatherings to 10 or fewer people.

Title/Description: Executive Order.
Comments: Extending professional and occupational licensing.

Title/Description: Executive Order.
Comments: Temporary allowing notaries and witnesses to act via audio-video technology.

Title/Description: The Kansas Supreme Court upheld the Governor’s executive order.
Comments: Limiting the size of mass gathering to 10 people, including that of church services and funerals.

Title/Description: Executive Order.
Comments: Extending the temporary relief for motor carriers from certain rules and regulations.

Title/Description: The Governor has extended the stay-at-home order until May 1st.
Executive Order.
Comments: Brings adult care homes in line with other occupational licensing exemptions. All state agencies working or collaborating with the Kansas Department for Aging and Disability Services shall extend renewal deadlines for any occupational or professional license, certificate or registration as needed.

Title/Description: Executive Order.
Comments: Extending the stay at home order to May 3.

Title/Description: The Governor stated that her state and other rural states have struggled to get medical supplies.
Comments: Her public health teams identifies as a prerequisite to easing social distancing requirements.

Title/Description: Kansas received additional supplies and personal protective equipment (PPE) from federal partners
Comments: to expand COVID-19 testing in Finney, Ford, Lyon and Seward counties.

Title/Description: the Kansas Department of Health and Environment (KDHE) has released new guidelines on COVID-19 testing.
Comments: People exhibiting two symptoms will now be able to get tested.

Title/Description: The Governor's administration has been in communication with the state’s impacted meat processing facilities’ representatives
Comments: Their employees and local health officials and those facilities have taken several steps to modify their production and shipping systems.

Title/Description: The state has coordinated with local agencies to secure temporary emergency housing for some people who have been isolated for observation or quarantined for two weeks in four counties
Comments: With large meatpacking plants affected by the virus.

Title/Description: Executive Order
Comments: Temporarily waiving physician supervision or collaboration requirements for certain medical licensees, including advanced practice registered nurses, physician assistants and licensed practical nurses.

Title/Description: Executive Order
Comments: The order also allows out-of-state health care providers to practice in Kansas.

Title/Description: Executive Order
Comments: Allowing for the sale of alcoholic beverages for carryout consumption and permits the sale of liquor in a container that is not the original container for any establishment holding a class A club license, class B club license or drinking establishment license.

Title/Description: Detailed framework for gradually, safely re-opening the economy and getting Kansas back to work, via Executive Order 20-29.
Comments: Phase One will take effect on Monday, May 4, 2020, via Executive Order 20-29, when the statewide stay-home order outlined in Executive Order 20-16 officially lifts.

Title/Description: The appointment of two individuals who will head the team charged with leading Kansas forward in recovery from the far-reaching effects of COVID-19.
Comments: The Governor selected Cheryl Harrison-Lee as the Recovery Office’s executive director and Lyle Butler as the chair.

Title/Description: Executive Order 20- 31
Comments: Establishes a new phase to the “Ad Astra: Plan to Reopen Kansas.” The new “1.5” Phase, effective May 18, 2020, continues reopening efforts while preserving some data-driven restrictions necessary to prevent community transmission of COVID-19.

Title/Description: Executive Order.
Comments: Provides temporary relief from certain restrictions concerning shared work programs. The order waives a provision in the law that prohibited a contributing negative account employer to participate in a shared work plan.

Title/Description: Executive Order.
Comments: To extend temporary relief for motor carriers from certain rules and regulations until rescinded, on June 15, 2020, or until the statewide State of Disaster Emergency expires, whichever is earlier. It is an extension of measures put in place by Executive Order #20-22.

Title/Description: The Governor will meet with President Trump at the White House on Wednesday
Comments: To discuss how to protect the U.S. food supply and agricultural sector amid COVID-19.

Title/Description: The Strengthening People and Revitalizing Kansas (SPARK) Taskforce to lead the state’s economic recovery.
Comments: The Recovery Office team will be responsible for the statewide distribution of significant CARES Act funding. A five-member executive committee will oversee the process, and the office will have a steering committee with an additional 15 members who will form three subcommittees. The three subcommittees will focus on communication and engagement, finance and policy development and implementation and accountability.

Title/Description: Executive Order 20-34
Comments: Moves Kansas into Phase 2 of Ad Astra: A Plan to Reopen Kansas.

Title/Description: Vetoing House Bill 2054.
Signed a new state disaster declaration.
Called for a special session starting June 3 and deliver an emergency management bill.
Discussing this week how to spend $1.25 billion in federal relief funds.
Comments: The Governor announced that the team she appointed to help her plan for the state’s economic recovery from the coronavirus pandemic will begin discussing this week how to spend $1.25 billion in federal relief funds.

Title/Description: The Governor’s Strengthening People and Revitalizing Kansas (SPARK) Taskforce Executive Committee reviewed and approved a proposal to distribute $400 million.
Comments: To local governments to help address the health and economic challenges inflicted by COVID-19.

Title/Description: An award of nearly $9 million in Community Development Block Grant Coronavirus Response Supplement (CDBG-CV) funds to 66 Kansas communities.
Most local communities consider moving into Phase 3 of “Ad Astra: A Plan to Reopen Kansas.”
Comments: The Governor's administration, as well as officials with the Kansas Department of Health and Environment, recommend this.

Title/Description: The State Finance Council approved the distribution of $400 million in funding from the Coronavirus Relief Fund to local Kansas governments.
Comments: To help combat the health and economic challenges COVID-19 has brought on their communities, and to help prepare for possible future outbreaks of the disease.

Title/Description: Executive Order #20-46.
Comments: Offers temporary relief from age restrictions that prohibit applicants 50 years of age or older from applying to renew their driver’s license online. Under the new order, all drivers under the age of 65 are permitted to use the online renewal system.

Title/Description: Governor's recommendation that communities do not move into Phase Out of “Ad Astra: A Plan to Reopen Kansas,”.
Comments: Originally planned to begin June 22, and instead stay in Phase 3 for at least two more weeks.

Title/Description: A new customer service hotline and email for Kansans who have been affected by the recent duplicate payments.
The Governor directed the Kansas Department of Revenue to begin phasing in the availability of drive tests.
The Governor will sign an Executive Order requiring that most Kansans in a public space must wear a mask.
Comments: Beginning 12:01 a.m. Friday, July 3.

Title/Description: Executive Order.
Comments: Drivers’ license and vehicle registration and regulation during state of disaster emergency.

Title/Description: Executive Order.
Comments: Allowing certain deferred tax deadlines and payments during state of disaster emergency.

Title/Description: Executive Order.
Comments: Extending professional and occupational licenses during state of disaster emergency.

Title/Description: Executive Order.
Comments: Temporarily allowing notaries and witnesses to act via audio-video communication technology during state of disaster emergency.

Title/Description: Executive Order.
Comments: Licensure, Certification, and Registration for persons and Licensure of “Adult Care Homes” during state of disaster emergency.

Title/Description: Executive Order.
Comments: Temporarily suspending certain rules relating to the sale of alcoholic beverages during state of disaster emergency.

Title/Description: Executive Order.
Comments: Temporary relief from certain restrictions concerning shared work programs during state of disaster emergency.

Title/Description: Executive Order.
Comments: Requiring that masks be worn statewide.

Title/Description: State of emergency
Issued guidance.
Comments: Issued guidance for high risk populations, as well as state employees on how to protect themselves and others (modifications for sick leave).

Title/Description: Nursing home limitations
Comments: Kentucky nursing homes will be limiting patient visits

Title/Description: School closure preparation.
Comments: school districts to be prepared to close schools on short notice

Title/Description: Prison visitations restrictions.
Comments: Closed all state prisons to visitors

Title/Description: Out of state travel restriction
Comments: Suspended out-of-state travel for state employees

Title/Description: Remote work
Comments: Urged more businesses to allow employees to tele-commute and to provide paid sick leave

Title/Description: Places of workship temporarily canceled.
Comments: Asked places of worship to temporarily cancel services.

Title/Description: Hospital limitations
Comments: Governer asked all Kentucky hospitals to cease providing elective surgery and for daycare facilities to begin planning for closures.

Title/Description: Restaurant and bar closure.
Comments: All bars and restaurant and dining rooms to close.

Title/Description: Childcare center closure
Comments: All childcare centers, with the exception of those providing services to health care workers and some on-site employers, will close by March 20.

Title/Description: Public facing businesses closure
Comments: Public-facing businesses that must close include entertainment, hospitality and recreational facilities, community and recreation centers, gyms and exercise facilities, hair salons, nail salons, spas, concert venues, theaters, and sporting event facilities.

Title/Description: Acute care visitation limitaitons
Comments: All acute care facilities should discourage all visitors except for visits in end-of-life circumstances.

Title/Description: Phyciatric Facility visitation limitations.
Comments: The Governor advised psychiatric facilities to restrict visitation, only allowing it if deemed medically necessary by the attending physician, administrator and the medical director.

Title/Description: Visitation limitations of personal care homes, senior care facilities, and intermediate care facilities.
Comments: The Governor recommended personal care homes, assisted living, senior care facilities and intermediate care facilities limit visitation only to loved ones that are receiving end-of-life care.

Title/Description: Driver lecense extension.
Comments: The Governor announced a three-month extension of driver’s licenses.

Title/Description: Primary election postponement.
Comments: The Governor announced postponement of primary elections

Title/Description: Public facing businesses closure
Comments: Several new actions to supplement previous guidance for closing public-facing businesses, including the suspension of all charitable gaming licenses and temporary closing of bingo halls.

Title/Description: Child Care Assistance
Comments: the state is working with federal partners to continue Child Care Assistance Program payments on behalf of qualified families during the mandatory closure period. The state will also be covering copayments typically covered by families.

Title/Description: Delivery options for restaurants.
Comments: Allowing restaurants that have food delivery options.

Title/Description: Delivery of liquor.
Comments: A liquor license to deliver sealed alcoholic beverages in their original containers to customers.

Title/Description: Kentucky Unemployment Insurance implements procedures for influx of claims.
Comments: Including new phonelines and video conference services.

Title/Description: School Closures
Comments: School superintendents keep schools closed for in-person classes until at least April 20 and delayed the state’s income tax filing deadline until July 15.

Title/Description: Closing of nonessential retailers.
Comments: All nonessential retailers to close within 24 hours and that he is mandating all elective medical procedures to end.

Title/Description: Changes in mass layoff parameters
Comments: Any employer with at least 50 employees, who is laying off at least 15 employees, is encouraged to file a claim on behalf of their employees through the E-Claims process.

Title/Description: Establish the Team Kentucky Fund
Comments: A fundraising platform designed to provide financial assistance to Kentuckians whose employment has been affected by COVID-19

Title/Description: In person service bussinesses closure.
Comments: All non-life sustaining business to close in-person service.

Title/Description: State workers would begin helping at food banks.
Hand sanitizers made for hospitals and first responders.
Comments: Many businesses, including food and beverage industries, are making barrels of hand sanitizers for hospitals and first responders.

Title/Description: The Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) approve Kentucky’s request for a Section 1135 Medicaid waiver.
Comments: The approved waiver enables Kentucky to provide flexibilities in Medicaid provider screening and enrollment, forgo certain pre-admission screening and annual resident review assessments, lift prior authorization requirements, allow for reimbursement facility services in alternative settings, and extend fair hearing and appeals timelines.

Title/Description: School Closure.
Comments: The governor signed legislation waiving in-person school attendance requirements and giving school districts permission to engage in nontraditional/remote learning.

Title/Description: The Governor asked mayors and county judge-executives to monitor people gathering in public places.
Comments: Such as parks and stop them if people are not practicing social distancing.

Title/Description: Residents to avoid crossing into Tennessee to limit their exposure to COVID-19.
Executive Order
Comments: Limiting out of state travel for residents of Kentucky, except when required for employment, to obtain medicine or groceries, to seek or obtain care by a healthcare provider, to provide care to dependents or when mandated by court order.

Title/Description: The National Guard would be assisting to help feed seniors and displaced workers.
Recommendation for school districts to extend their suspension of in-person instruction to at least May 1.
Plans to commute the sentences of hundreds of non-violent offenders.
All state parks would be closed for overnight stays.
Move plans forward to convert state fairgrounds in Louisville into a 2,000 hospital makeshift bed.
The Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) approved Kentucky’s request to recover Medicaid federal match rates
New initiative aimed at making it easier for people to donate personal protective equipment (PPE).
Call to action.
Comments: For any person, organization or business that can donate more personal protective equipment (PPE) for frontline workers.

Title/Description: Allow first responders and front-line health care workers to quarantine in cabins at state parks in five locations across the commonwealth
Comments: Which would allow them to quarantine away from their families and other loved ones if necessary.

Title/Description: Kentucky received the federal funding stream.
Comments: To begin making the additional $600 per week payment to those Kentuckians receiving unemployment insurance benefits.

Title/Description: Extended a previous Executive Order.
Comments: Allows pharmacists to dispense emergency refills for up to another 30-day supply of non-scheduled medications to Kentucky residents.

Title/Description: Individuals who attend an in-person worship service or mass gathering of any kind Easter Weekend will face quarantine orders.
The United Postal Service (UPS) donated 16,000 N95 masks.
The Honorable Order of Kentucky Colonels made $1 million gift to the Team Kentucky Fund.
The Governor has joined a partnership with 6 other states in the region (Michigan, Ohio, Wisconsin, Minnesota, Illinois, and Indiana) to develop a plan for reopening the region economy.
An expansion of the state’s partnership with Kroger to provide drive-through testing for the coronavirus.
14 days where cases are decreasing.
Comments: Benchmarks that must be met in order to start reopening the state’s economy

Title/Description: Increased testing capacity and contact tracing.
Comments: Benchmarks that must be met in order to start reopening the state’s economy

Title/Description: Personal protective equipment (PPE) availability.
Ability to protect at-risk populations.
Ability to social distance and follow Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) guidelines on large gatherings.
Preparedness for a possible future spike.
Status of vaccine and treatment.
The creation of a new Long-Term Care Task Force.
Comments: It will assist the Kentuckians most vulnerable to COVID-19 and the healthcare workers who serve them.

Title/Description: The commonwealth’s education leaders to keep facilities closed to in-person instruction for the rest of the school year.
The launch of “Healthy at Work,” a new initiative.
Comments: To help Kentucky businesses reopen safely. Healthy at Work offers a phased approach to reopening Kentucky’s economy, based on criteria set by public health experts and advice from industry experts.

Title/Description: The phased restart of Kentucky’s economy will begin on Monday, April 27th.
Comments: With a segment of the health care services industry. Initially, the easing of restrictions will allow for diagnostic and radiology testing, as well as non-urgent, emergent, in-person office and ambulatory visits.

Title/Description: On April 27, the state will begin the gradual restart and reopening of the Phase 1 health care services and facilities
Kentucky has received more than $450,000 in funding to provide novel coronavirus (COVID-19) prevention, preparedness and response assistance.
Comments: To non-profit arts organizations.

Title/Description: The Governor and Secretary of State Michael Adams have reached an agreement on how the state’s primary elections, special elections and local option elections.
Comments: Scheduled for June 23, 2020.

Title/Description: Executive Order.
Comments: The expansion and promotion of absentee ballots.

Title/Description: Executive Order.
Comments: Prioritizing voting by appointment.

Title/Description: Executive Order.
Comments: PPE for clerks and poll workers.

Title/Description: Kentucky’s local public safety agencies and eligible local governments can apply for part of more than $9 million in grant funding from the U.S. Department of Justice’s (USDOJ) Coronavirus Emergency Supplemental Funding Program (CESF).
The expansion of testing sites across the state.
By May 11 everybody working for an essential business that is reopening should be wearing a mask.
Phase 1 in reopening of the healthcare industry in the state with practitioners being able to resume non-urgent/emergent health care services, diagnostic radiology and lab services.
Comments: Hospital outpatient settings.

Title/Description: Phase 1 in reopening of the healthcare industry in the state with practitioners being able to resume non-urgent/emergent health care services, diagnostic radiology and lab services.
Comments: Health care clinics and medical offices.

Title/Description: Phase 1 in reopening of the healthcare industry in the state with practitioners being able to resume non-urgent/emergent health care services, diagnostic radiology and lab services.
Comments: Physical therapy settings, chiropractic offices and optometrists.

Title/Description: Phase 1 in reopening of the healthcare industry in the state with practitioners being able to resume non-urgent/emergent health care services, diagnostic radiology and lab services.
Comments: Dental offices (but with enhanced aerosol protections).

Title/Description: The state is preparing to hire more than 700 people to help with contact tracing.
New guidelines to help businesses reopen, a new, 10-point plan that aims to guide businesses as they prepare for a gradual reopening while continuing to keep all workers and patrons safe.
Comments: Continue telework where possible.

Title/Description: New guidelines to help businesses reopen, a new, 10-point plan that aims to guide businesses as they prepare for a gradual reopening while continuing to keep all workers and patrons safe.
Comments: Phased return to work.

Title/Description: New guidelines to help businesses reopen, a new, 10-point plan that aims to guide businesses as they prepare for a gradual reopening while continuing to keep all workers and patrons safe.
Comments: Onsite temperature/health checks.

Title/Description: New guidelines to help businesses reopen, a new, 10-point plan that aims to guide businesses as they prepare for a gradual reopening while continuing to keep all workers and patrons safe.
Comments: Universal masks and other necessary PPE.

Title/Description: New guidelines to help businesses reopen, a new, 10-point plan that aims to guide businesses as they prepare for a gradual reopening while continuing to keep all workers and patrons safe.
Comments: Close common areas.

Title/Description: New guidelines to help businesses reopen, a new, 10-point plan that aims to guide businesses as they prepare for a gradual reopening while continuing to keep all workers and patrons safe.
Comments: Enforce social distancing.

Title/Description: New guidelines to help businesses reopen, a new, 10-point plan that aims to guide businesses as they prepare for a gradual reopening while continuing to keep all workers and patrons safe.
Comments: Limit face-to-face meetings.

Title/Description: New guidelines to help businesses reopen, a new, 10-point plan that aims to guide businesses as they prepare for a gradual reopening while continuing to keep all workers and patrons safe.
Comments: Sanitizer/hand wash stations.

Title/Description: New guidelines to help businesses reopen, a new, 10-point plan that aims to guide businesses as they prepare for a gradual reopening while continuing to keep all workers and patrons safe.
Comments: Special accommodations.

Title/Description: New guidelines to help businesses reopen, a new, 10-point plan that aims to guide businesses as they prepare for a gradual reopening while continuing to keep all workers and patrons safe.
Comments: Testing plan.

Title/Description: Unveiled a tentative reopening schedule for a variety of businesses allowed to resume operations.
Comments: The plan would require businesses to adhere to the 10 rules to reopening, along with industry specific requirements. The Governor also identified the following industries that will not be able to reopen yet as restaurants, gyms, movie theaters, campgrounds, youth sports, summer camps, day cares (except for essential health care workers) and public pools

Title/Description: New businesses that would be eligible to reopen operations under Phase 1 starting May 11th.
Comments: Manufacturing, distribution and supply chain businesses.

Title/Description: New businesses that would be eligible to reopen operations under Phase 1 starting May 11th.
Comments: Construction.

Title/Description: New businesses that would be eligible to reopen operations under Phase 1 starting May 11th.
Comments: Vehicle or vessel dealerships.

Title/Description: New businesses that would be eligible to reopen operations under Phase 1 starting May 11th.
Comments: Office-based businesses (at 50% pre-pandemic capacity).

Title/Description: New businesses that would be eligible to reopen operations under Phase 1 starting May 11th.
Comments: Horse racing (no fans in attendance).

Title/Description: New businesses that would be eligible to reopen operations under Phase 1 starting May 11th.
Comments: Pet care, grooming and boarding.

Title/Description: New businesses that would be eligible to reopen operations under Phase 1 starting May 11th.
Comments: Photography.

Title/Description: Kentucky Department for Public Health (KDPH) Commissioner announced Health Care Phase 2 will begin Wednesday, May 6, 2020
Comments: Outpatient and ambulatory surgery and invasive procedures may resume.

Title/Description: A new partnership with St. Elizabeth Healthcare to bring expanded testing in Northern Kentucky.
A partnership with the Kentucky Chamber of Commerce and the Kentucky Distillers’ Association.
Comments: To get personal protective equipment (PPE) and hand sanitizer to small businesses as they prepare to be Healthy at Work.

Title/Description: The Governor urged voters to get ready to request absentee ballots.
The Governor announced help from the Kentucky National Guard.
Comments: National Guard leaders offered to help and members will work as poll workers and keep polling places operating safely.

Title/Description: The Governor's administration is changing its travel restrictions to better comply with judicial findings and more closely mirror the guidance of neighboring states.
Comments: The Governor issued a new executive order that continues to ban anyone with a positive or presumptively positive case of COVID-19 from entering Kentucky, except as ordered for medical treatment. It also keeps in place requirements of social distancing on public transportation.

Title/Description: The Kentucky Department for Public Health (KDPH) Commissioner said Health Care Phase 2 is beginning.
Comments: With outpatient and ambulatory surgery and invasive procedures.

Title/Description: The Kentucky Transportation Cabinet (KYTC) has been awarded nearly $22.9 million for relief of public transit agencies that have been hit hard by the deadly COVID-19 pandemic.
Comments: The funding will sustain the transit agencies by covering some operational expenses, including administrative leave for employees forced to self-isolate because of exposure to people infected with COVID-19.

Title/Description: The second phase of reopening.
Comments: May 22 – Restaurants, with limited 33% capacity and outdoor seating

Title/Description: The second phase of reopening.
Comments: June 1 – Movie theaters, fitness centers.

Title/Description: The second phase of reopening.
Comments: June 11 – Campgrounds, public and private.

Title/Description: The second phase of reopening.
Comments: June 15 – Child care, with reduced capacity; and potentially low-touch and outdoor youth sports.

Title/Description: The Governor outlined the requirements to begin reopening major segments of the economy and society.
Comments: including houses of worship, manufacturing, construction, government offices and agencies, retail and funeral services.

Title/Description: The Kentucky Department for Public Health (KDPH) announced a new long-term care testing strategy, in partnership with Norton Healthcare and local health departments and emergency management leaders.
Comments: All long-term care facilities will be risk-stratified based on eight key metrics. There will be COVID-19 surveillance testing for residents and staff in all 286 skilled nursing facilities in the Kentucky.

Title/Description: New partnerships with First Care Clinics and Bluewater Diagnostics Laboratory.
