Comments: It will help Kentuckians get tested for COVID-19 at no cost before they go back to work, even if they do not have health insurance.

Title/Description: A scam alert today warning Kentuckians of utility-related scams
Comments: Arising in the midst of the novel coronavirus pandemic.

Title/Description: The Kentucky Education and Workforce Development Cabinet (KEWDC) has been awarded more than $43.7 million from the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act.
Comments: For education programs that have been affected by the COVID-19 pandemic.

Title/Description: The appointment of an executive advisor leading the contact tracing efforts in the Office of the Secretary of the Cabinet for Health and Family Services (CHFS).
A $300 million award to city and county governments as part of the Coronavirus Aid, Relief and Economic Security (CARES) Act.
Comments: Which established the Coronavirus Relief Fund (CRF) to reimburse local governments for expenses incurred in response to the public health emergency caused by the novel coronavirus 2019 (COVID-19).

Title/Description: Cabinet for Health and Family Services (CHFS) Secretary announced that in-home child care programs can open on June 8.
Comments: Center-based licensed child care programs can reopen to all families on June 15.

Title/Description: Auctions could be held starting June 1.
Comments: Horse shows can be held again starting on June 8. Bars, gatherings with 50 people or fewer, and venues that hold 50 people or fewer can reopen June 29 if they meet guidelines.

Title/Description: The Kentucky Cabinet for Health and Family Services (CHFS) Department for Community Based Services (DCBS) and the Kentucky Department of Education are partnering to provide food assistance.
Comments: To families who have lost access to free or reduced-price school meals during the COVID-19 public health emergency.

Title/Description: The Governor encouraged all voters to use a new Absentee Ballot Application Portal.
Comments: Now available online.

Title/Description: The Governor is reorganizing the Executive Branch Ethics Commission.
Comments: In order to strengthen its mission.

Title/Description: The Governor with the Department of Local Governments announced more than $5 million in grants to six local governments.
Comments: For water and sewer projects across Kentucky.

Title/Description: An official order temporarily authorizing circuit court clerk offices to process expired driving credential renewals and replacement requests remotely.

The Governor and Cabinet for Health and Family Services Secretary announced the Commonwealth of Kentucky has awarded the state’s Medicaid Managed Care Organization (MCO) contract to five health care companies.
Comments: The five health care companies that will manage benefits for the state’s Medicaid enrollees.

Title/Description: The Governor has reached an agreement with legislative leaders to avoid the need for the General Assembly to return in a special session to resolve budget matters.
The Department of Corrections is currently mass testing all inmates and staff at the Kentucky Correctional Institute for Women (KCIW) in Shelby County.
Comments: The decision comes after three staffers and 11 inmates tested positive for COVID-19. More than 270 of the facility’s 639 inmates have been tested thus far.

Title/Description: Governor directed his administration to provide personal protective equipment (PPE) to keep voters and poll workers safe during Kentucky’s primaries.
Comments: The Governor’s office is providing 5,000 masks, 4,000 gallons of hand sanitizer, 5,800 face shields and 20,000 gloves for the June 23 election. The PPE will be distributed to all 120 counties.

Title/Description: The Governor's intention to move Kentucky back to the healthcare exchange.
The Governor's new guidance for venues like restaurants and bars and other venues.
Comments: For venues that would have gatherings of 50 people or fewer.

Title/Description: The national guard will have plain clothes individuals assisting with polling places on election day.
$383 million in state and federal dollars for 54 rural hospitals.
Comments: By settling a 13-year-old dispute regarding Medicaid funding rates.

Title/Description: The Governor and the Commissioner for the state department of education released initial guidance on school reopening.
COVID-19 Task Force.
Public Health Emergency
Comments: Allows state agencies to thoroughly prepare for any eventuality related to public health needs and deploy additional resources to assist local authorities. The declaration also addresses efforts to prevent price gouging and limits state employee travel.

Title/Description: Executive order: Postponing elections.
Comments: Postponing elections in Louisiana, including the Louisiana Presidential Primary.

Title/Description: Limits public gatherings.
Comments: Immediately halts any gathering of more than 250 people until April 13.

Title/Description: School closures.
Comments: Closure of all K-12 public schools statewide effective March 16 until April 13.

Title/Description: Public facing businesses closure
Comments: Bars, gyms and movie theaters to close and limited restaurants to delivery and takeout.

Title/Description: Limits public gatherings.
Comments: Reducing the spread of COVID-19 by further limiting the size of gatherings to fewer than 50 people, closing casinos, bars and movie theaters

Title/Description: Restaurant limitations
Comments: Limiting restaurants to delivery, take out and drive-through orders only.

Title/Description: Request for Economic Injury Disaster Loans
Comments: the Small Business Administration provide Economic Injury Disaster Loans for Orleans and Jefferson parishes.

Title/Description: Preparation for shelter.
Comments: Shelter in place may be necessary for some Louisiana localities to stem the spread of COVID-19.

Title/Description: Prohibit evictions and foreclosures
Comments: The governor suspended oreclosures and evictions in the state.

Title/Description: Digital driver license
Comments: LA Wallet, the state of Louisiana’s official digital driver’s license, will be made available to residents free of charge. The all-digital identification and driver’s license app will temporarily suspend fees.

Title/Description: Sent to Trump and Pence requesting temporary changes to federal programs
Comments: An expansion of the Department of Agriculture’s Food and Nutrition Service hot food waiver to allow the purchase of hot food in Louisiana restaurants through the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program

Title/Description: Sent to Trump and Pence requesting temporary changes to federal programs
Comments: Statutory and administrative changes related to Community Development Block Grants for Disaster Recovery;

Title/Description: Sent to Trump and Pence requesting temporary changes to federal programs
Comments: Recommendations for FEMA’s Individual Assistance Program and Public Assistance program.

Title/Description: Exceeding patient treatment capacity.
Comments: The Governor warned President that his state could exceed capacity to treat patients in one week.

Title/Description: Update of Public Health Emergency
Comments: Declaration to provide waivers for education requirements and to speed up testing.

Title/Description: Parish Aid
Comments: All Louisiana parishes would be eligible for small business disaster aid.

Title/Description: Updated the Public Health Emergency.
Statewide stay-at-home order
The Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) approved Louisiana's request for a Section 1135 Medicaid waiver.
Request for Major Disaster Declaration for the State of Louisiana.
Comments: The Governor requested, as the number of cases of COVID-19 grow. The declaration would allow the federal government to provide additional support for state and local agencies in dealing with this growing public health threat.

Title/Description: Proclamation outlining additional response measures in Louisiana
Comments: Including provisions related to first responders, law enforcement and granting emergency authority to the insurance commissioner.

Title/Description: The opening of a Louisiana Economic Development help desk.
Comments: Providing email and hotline support for Louisiana businesses impacted by COVID-19.

Title/Description: A new Loan Portfolio Guaranty Program
Comments: Will offer loans of up to $100,000 to Louisiana small businesses of fewer than 100 employees that are impacted by the COVID-19 crisis.

Title/Description: Eased eligibility requirements for the Taylor Opportunity Program for Students
Comments: Provides tuition assistance for Louisiana residents.

Title/Description: A new text alert system that will provide timely COVID-19 updates and other critical guidance.
Comments: Directly from the governor’s office to Louisiana residents.

Title/Description: The Governor formally extended his Stay at Home order until April 30.
Comments: Extends the length of time that schools and some businesses are closed and continues limits on the size of gatherings.

Title/Description: Executive Order.
Comments: Related to unemployment and other issues related to the Louisiana Workforce Commission, as it seeks to manage the influx in unemployment claims.

Title/Description: The Governor’s response fund approved the first grant from the Governor’s COVID-19 Response Fund.
Comments: Will feed children in southern Louisiana.

Title/Description: The creation of a Healthy Equity Task Force.
Comments: Will look at how health inequities are affecting communities that are most impacted by the coronavirus.

Title/Description: The Governor postponed Louisiana’s election again.
Comments: Now rescheduled for July 11th.

Title/Description: The Governor signed a proclamation closing K-12 public schools in Louisiana to students until the end of the current school year
Comments: With students getting their education via remote learning.

Title/Description: The Governor announced the creation of Resilient Louisiana.
Comments: A state commission charged with examining Louisiana’s economy amid the COVID-19 pandemic and making recommendations for more resilient business-related activities and commerce in the coming months.

Title/Description: The Louisiana Department of Health issued a revised order for medical and surgical procedures. Go into effect April 27th.
Comments: To treat an emergency medical condition.

Title/Description: The Louisiana Department of Health issued a revised order for medical and surgical procedures. Go into effect April 27th.
Comments: To avoid further harms from an underlying condition or disease.

Title/Description: The Louisiana Department of Health issued a revised order for medical and surgical procedures. Go into effect April 27th.
Comments: To treat time sensitive conditions.

Title/Description: Two co-chairs and appointed members to the Louisiana COVID-19 Health Equity Task Force and several subcommittees.
Comments: Dr. Sandra C. Brown, Dean of Southern University’s College of Nursing and Allied Health and  Dr. Thomas LaVeist, Dean of Tulane University’s School of Public Health and Tropical Medicine.

Title/Description: The stay-at-home order is extended until May 15.
The Governor will be traveling to Washington, D.C. to meet with President Trump.
Comments: To discuss the states’ response to COVID-19.

Title/Description: The Governor released two new PSAs encouraging Louisianans to comply with the extended Stay at Home Order.
Comments: To slow the spread of Covid-19 and ultimately meet the White House guidelines for entering Phase One.

Title/Description: The Governor has activated a new, web-based program to assist businesses and religious organizations with safely resuming operations.
The State has committed $10,382,000 in community development block grant (CDBG) funds to the City of New Orleans.
Comments: To support nine affordable rental housing projects that were in danger of losing their funding as a result of the response to the COVID-19 outbreak.

Title/Description: The Governor and the Louisiana Department of Health outlined a plan for COVID-19 testing and tracking.
Comments: It would hire as many as 700 Louisianans to serve as contact tracers.

Title/Description: The Governor will move to Phase One under the White House COVID-19 guidance Friday, May 15.
Comments: Removes the Stay at Home order for Louisianans and allows additional businesses to open under strict occupancy, protection and social distancing guidelines.

Title/Description: The Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) approved Louisiana’s second request for a Medicaid 1135 waiver.
Comments: The waiver allows Louisiana to lift prior authorization requirements, waive consent requirements for Home and Community-Based Services (HCBS), to modify timelines for levels of care determinations, and to reimburse for personal care provided by legally responsible individuals, including family caregivers.

Title/Description: Louisiana will enter into Phase One of its Roadmap to a Resilient Louisiana on Friday, May 15.
Comments: The Stay at Home order will be lifted and more businesses will be allowed to open with strict social distancing, enhanced sanitation and required masks for employees helping the public.

Title/Description: A U.S. District Judge of the Middle District of Louisiana denied Rev. Tony Spell’s motion for a Temporary Restraining Order against Gov. John Bel Edwards’ Stay at Home order.
The state is ready to move to Phase 2 of the White House’s reopening strategy on June 5.
Louisiana will stay in Phase Two of reopening.
Comments: The number of COVID-19 cases and related hospitalizations have started to rise in several regions across the state. The Governor will extend his Phase Two order for another 28 days, keeping in place occupancy limits and other restrictions.

Title/Description: The state will be postponing Phase 3 of reopening.
Comments: Due to the increase in COVID-19 cases.

Title/Description: Coronavirus Response Team
Gathering limitaions
Comments: Gatherings with more than 250 people be postponed

Title/Description: State employee travel restrictions
Comments: The Governor announced that she is suspending all non-essential travel by state employees

Title/Description: Civil emergency
Comments: The Governor signed a proclamation of civil emergency.

Title/Description: Emergency legislation approved by the House and Senate including key provisions.
Comments: Access to at least $11 million in state funding to respond to COVID-19.

Title/Description: Emergency legislation approved by the House and Senate including key provisions.
Comments: Establishing a consumer loan guarantee program through the Finance Authority of Maine, in partnership with financial institutions, to provide low- or no-interest loans for eligible people in Maine

Title/Description: Emergency legislation approved by the House and Senate including key provisions.
Comments: Temporarily expanding eligibility for unemployment benefits for workers impacted by COVID-19.

Title/Description: Emergency legislation approved by the House and Senate including key provisions.
Comments: Increasing the Department of Education’s ability to waive certain school-day requirements and to continue school lunch programs for all eligible children.

Title/Description: Emergency legislation approved by the House and Senate including key provisions.
Comments: Authorizing the Governor to adjust state, county and municipal government deadlines and to permit all public entities to meet by remote participation

Title/Description: Emergency legislation approved by the House and Senate including key provisions.
Comments: Expanding the ability of Maine Emergency Medical Services’ Board and staff to take actions more promptly

Title/Description: Emergency legislation approved by the House and Senate including key provisions.
Comments: Authorizing the Governor to prohibit utilities from terminating residential electric and water service.

Title/Description: Emergency legislation approved by the House and Senate including key provisions.
Comments: Authorizing the Governor to determine and direct the manner of the June 2020 primary, if necessary.

Title/Description: Exective Order of restaurant closure.
Comments: Closes restaurant dining rooms, bars, and limited social gatherings to no greater than 10 people.

Title/Description: Maine Health Care Coverage Act
Comments: Created in order to improve private health insurance in the state.

Title/Description: Recreational fishing license required.
Comments: The Governor ordered open open all inland waters for fishing and waived the requirement that anglers need a recreational fishing license to fish the inland waters of Maine. The order is effective immediately and runs until April 30th.

Title/Description: Letter to the president
Comments: Requesting that the Trump Administration consider direct financial assistance, subsidies, and operating loans or loan deferment, among other possible measures, to help the seafood industry.

Title/Description: Limiting in person conact in businesses.
Comments: Large essential businesses to limit in-store customers, enhance curbside pick-up and delivery services, and implement physical distancing measures to protect customer and employee health

Title/Description: Executive Order
Comments: Mandated all non-essential businesses and operations in Maine close their physical locations that are public facing.

Title/Description: Agreements to coordinate requests for assistance and the deployment of resources.
Comments: The Governor, through the Maine Emergency Management Agency, signed agreements with the University of Maine System and the Maine Community College System to coordinate requests for assistance and the deployment of resources.

Title/Description: Insurance emergency response order
Comments: Receive an emergency license to provide health care in person or through telehealth to Maine people, with no application fee

Title/Description: Insurance emergency response order
Comments: See Maine patients through telehealth without obtaining a Maine license, if already serving those patients at out-of-state locations

Title/Description: Insurance emergency response order
Comments: Have their (physicians, physician assistants, and nurses) licenses automatically renewed if up for renewal during the state of emergency

Title/Description: Insurance emergency response order
Comments: Suspend conforming to physician oversight requirements (for physician assistants and advanced practice registered nurses)

Title/Description: Insurance emergency response order
Comments: Reactivate their license immediately with no application fee, if retired.

Title/Description: Affordability of needed health care services delivered through telehealth.
Comments: The Governor took action to align Maine with federal guidance and improves the affordability of needed health care services delivered through telehealth.

Title/Description: Stay at home order for the state that will continue to April 30th.
A major disaster declaration from the federal government.
Extended the state property tax deadline.
Executive Order.
Comments: Mandating that travelers arriving in Maine, regardless of their state of residency, self-quarantine for 14 days.

Title/Description: The President has approved her request for a major disaster declaration for the State of Maine.
Executive Order.
Comments: To further expand access to health care by taking additional steps to bolster the health care workforce, expand telehealth services, and temporarily alleviate certain licensing requirements.

Title/Description: Maine National Guard and the Maine Emergency Management Agency (MEMA) are to work with Maine’s health care systems to open two alternative care sites in Portland and Bangor.
Comments: As part of the State’s preparations to bolster Maine health system capacity.

Title/Description: The Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) approved Maine’s request for a Section 1135 Medicaid waiver
Comments: The approved waiver enables Maine to provide flexibilities in Medicaid provider screening and enrollment, forgo certain pre-admission screening and annual resident review assessments, lift prior authorization requirements, allow for reimbursement facility services in alternative settings, extend fair hearing timelines, and waive public comment and tribal consultation requirements for certain changes to the Medicaid state plan.

Title/Description: Executive order.
Comments: Allowing remote notarizations.

Title/Description: Executive order.
Comments: Moving Maine’s primary election from Tuesday, June 9, 2020 to Tuesday, July 14, 2020. The order allows applications for absentee ballots to be made in writing or in person, without specifying a reason, up to and including the day of the election.

Title/Description: The Governor joined a coalition of Governors from Delaware, Illinois, Michigan, Montana, New Jersey, New Mexico, North Carolina, Oregon, Pennsylvania, Virginia and Wisconsin in writing to U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) Secretary Alex Azar and Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) Administrator Seema Verma.
Comments: To ask the Administration to reconsider its decision and take action to allow for a special enrollment period of at least 30 days on the federal health care exchange.

Title/Description: Governor wrote a letter urging U.S. Secretary of Agriculture Sonny Perdue.
Comments: To coordinate a nationwide strategy to increase the amount of food available to emergency food programs and to address gaps in the food supply chain.

Title/Description: Extending Maine’s state of civil emergency for another thirty days through May 15, 2020.
Executive Order.
Comments: Will prevent the immediate eviction of tenants other than those who engage in dangerous or unlawful conduct for the duration of the state of emergency. The Governor also strengthened the penalties for landlords who may try to evict tenants by unlawful means, and she extended the timeframe for the eviction process in the event that the Courts reopen before the Governor’s state of emergency is terminated.

Title/Description: A new rental assistance relief program for Maine people who cannot pay their rent due to COVID-19.
Comments: The Governor in partnership with MaineHousing.

Title/Description: Federal funds will support access to child care for Maine’s essential workers.
Comments: Nearly $11 million in federal funds will support access to child care for Maine’s essential workers, including health care professionals and first responders, and offer relief for child care providers.

Title/Description: Gradual reopening.
Comments: Protecting public health

Title/Description: Gradual reopening.
Comments: Maintaining healthcare readiness

Title/Description: Gradual reopening.
Comments: Building reliable and accessible testing

Title/Description: Gradual reopening.
Comments: Prioritizing private-public collaboration

Title/Description: Convene off cycle to examine the economic ramifications of COVID-19
Comments: The Consensus Economic Forecasting Commission (CEFC) and the Revenue Forecasting Committee (RFC) will convene off cycle to examine the economic ramifications of COVID-19 on State government’s revenues.

Title/Description: plan to gradually and safely restart Maine’s economy
Comments: Four gradual stages of reopening, the first of which begins May 1st. The stages focus on the ability of a business to operate or an activity to occur in a manner that protects public health and safety. The Maine CDC will be tracking three primary metrics in its evaluation of whether or not to progress through the stages: 1) a downward trajectory of influenza-like illnesses and COVID-like syndromic cases; 2) a downward trajectory of documented cases and newly hospitalized patients; and 3) the capacity of Maine’s hospital systems to treat all patients without crisis care and the ability of the state to engage in a robust testing program.

Title/Description: Executive Order
Comments: Extending the stay-at-home order until May 31st. However, it now allows citizens to visit businesses or participate in activities deemed safe to open under Stage 1 of the reopening plan.

Title/Description: Economic Recovery Committee to mitigate the damage to Maine’s economy.
Comments: Convening an Economic Recovery Committee charged with developing recommendations to mitigate the damage to Maine’s economy caused by the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic and to jumpstart a long-term economic recovery for Maine people, businesses, and organizations.

Title/Description: Purchase of more COVID-19 testing kits.
Comments: The state has partnered with Maine-based IDEXX Laboratories, Inc. to purchase enough of the company’s recently authorized COVID-19 testing kits to more than triple the State’s testing capacity.

Title/Description: A rural reopening plan.
Comments: Aimed at reopening certain additional businesses in rural Maine over the course of the next two weeks with added health and safety measures. The plan comes after the Governor stated that her Administration was considering opportunities for regional variation as part of its Restarting Maine’s Economy plan.

Title/Description: The Maine Department of Health and Human Services (DHHS) launched a statewide campaign.
Comments: To promote awareness of affordable health insurance options, particularly for people whose employment or income has been affected by the COVID-19 pandemic.

Title/Description: A proclamation extending Maine’s state of civil emergency.
Comments: For thirty days through June 11, 2020.

Title/Description: Maine lodging providers can begin accepting future reservations for stays with an arrival date of June 1st and beyond.
Comments: For Maine residents and for non-residents who comply with the State’s 14-day quarantine requirement.

Title/Description: The Governor and the Maine Education Commissioner announced that the Maine Department of Education has secured internet access and devices.
Comments: To facilitate at home learning for 100 percent of Maine school children for whom there was a reported need.

Title/Description: The Maine Emergency Management Agency (MEMA) provided 1,900 cloth face coverings to the Maine Association of Broadcasters (MAB).
Comments: For distribution to the state’s broadcast media outlets.

Title/Description: Maine residents may enjoy campgrounds beginning Memorial Day weekend.
The Administration is delaying the full reopening of gyms, fitness centers, and nail salons.
Comments: Due to emerging research and experiences in other states of COVID-19 transmission related to these establishments.

Title/Description: The State of Maine has received $52.7 million in Federal grant funding from the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (U.S. CDC).
Comments: To bolster epidemiological and laboratory capacity to respond to infectious diseases, particularly COVID-19. The state will use this funding to enhance its ability to prevent, detect, and mitigate the spread of COVID-19 by expanding lab capacity and testing sites across Maine in the coming weeks and months.

Title/Description: The Maine Department of Health and Human Services (DHHS) is significantly expanding contact tracing.
Comments: By increasing the number of skilled staff and volunteers, harnessing innovative technology, and securing social services to help people with COVID-19 maintain self-isolation.

Title/Description: The Governor is postponing the full reopening of restaurants for dine-in services.
Comments: In York, Cumberland, and Androscoggin counties. The decision to limit their reopening comes amidst an increase in hospitalizations as well as an increase in case counts in these three counties.

Title/Description: Moody’s Investors Service and Standard & Poors Global Ratings (S&P) have affirmed their credit ratings and outlooks on the State of Maine’s general obligation debt.
Comments: Moody’s affirmed both their ‘Aa2 rating and stable outlook on Maine’s debt. S&P affirmed their AA rating and stable outlook.

Title/Description: The Maine Department of Corrections (MDOC) to offer to purchase perishable and non-perishable food from restaurants.
Comments: In York, Cumberland, and Androscoggin counties that are unable to open to indoor dining as a result of measures to protect public health and mitigate the spread of COVID-19.

Title/Description: The state will quadruple COVID-19 testing capacity at the State lab, develop testing sites throughout Maine, and allow more people in Maine with elevated risk of exposure to get tested for the virus.
Comments: This will come online in July.

Title/Description: An alternative to the State’s 14-day quarantine requirement for people entering Maine.
Comments: The plan rests on three cornerstones: 1) having visitors certify that they have received a recent negative COVID-19 test to stay in lodging establishments, such as hotels, as an alternative to quarantine; 2) increasing symptom checks at places where visitors tend to go; and 3) supporting community promotion of COVID-19 prevention best practices and public health education.

Title/Description: A renewal of the state’s civil emergency for thirty days through July 10th.
The Maine Department of Health and Human Services (DHHS) announced that 525 essential workers have received financial help for child care.
More than 1,600 child care providers have received stipends as part of the nearly $11 million in federal CARES Act funding awarded to Maine.
Comments: Additional grants will be awarded to child care providers through mid-July.

Title/Description: Indoor dining in Androscoggin, Cumberland, and York counties can voluntarily resume on Wednesday, June 17, 2020.
Comments: With added health and safety protocols outlined in the COVID-19 Prevention Checklist.

Title/Description: The Governor released a detailed guidance for Maine local governing bodies to hold gatherings.
Comments: Such as annual town meetings, school budget meetings, and elections, during the COVID-19 pandemic.

Title/Description: The Governor urged the USDA to designate maple syrup as an eligible Coronavirus Food Assistance Program (CFAP) specialty crop.
Comments: Doing so will create the pathway for Maine’s maple producers to receive needed CFAP payments.

Title/Description: The Governor's administration is postponing the reopening of indoor service at bars.
Comments: To protect public health given the higher risk of COVID-19 transmission in such settings.

Title/Description: The Governor posted additional COVID-19 Prevention Checklists for businesses and activities to voluntarily resume on July 1.
Comments: As part of Stage 3 of the Administration’s Restarting Maine’s Economy Plan .

Title/Description: The Governor announced that her administration is dedicating $35 million of Maine’s $1.25 billion in Coronavirus Relief Funding (CRF) provided through the CARES Act.
Comments: To help local and tribal governments and other qualified entities cover costs incurred as a result of COVID-19.

Title/Description: The Governor announced that her Administration has approved almost $9 million in grant awards to nearly 100 municipalities across the state under the Keep Maine Healthy Plan.
Comments: To support local COVID-19 public health, education, and prevention effort.

Title/Description: The Governor will be exempting visitors from the States of Connecticut, New York, and New Jersey from the 14-day quarantine requirement or negative COVID-19 testing alternative.
Comments: Effective this Friday, July 3, 2020.

Title/Description: The State Emergency Operation's Center activation level raised to "Enhanced" support.
The Maryland Department of Health (MDH) issued clinical guidance.
Comments: to the state’s 20,472 physicians, 2,786 nurse practitioners, 1,301 pharmacists, and local health departments. The department has held briefings for Maryland Strategic National Stockpile partners and public health and hospital emergency managers. In addition, the department has held an informational webinar for local health departments

Title/Description: MDH Public Service announcements.
Comments: Regarding statewide preparedness efforts.

Title/Description: Emergency funding request
Comments: Governor Hogan submits a $10 million emergency funding request to the General Assembly as part of a supplemental budget.

Title/Description: Return of studying abroad students.
Comments: The Maryland Higher Education Commission is coordinating with University System of Maryland institutions that are bringing home students who are studying abroad in Italy and Japan.

Title/Description: Nursing home and assisting living facility management
Comments: MDH is coordinating with nursing homes and assisted living facilities to review and reiterate guidance on infection control and medical management.

Title/Description: School management
Comments: MDH is coordinating with the Maryland State Department of Education (MSDE) to provide guidance to local school systems on protocols for school closures.

Title/Description: Hospital management
Comments: MDH is coordinating with the Maryland Hospital Association to work with all the local hospitals on surge plans and preparedness.

Title/Description: Traveling precautions and management.
Comments: The Maryland Department of Transportation (MDOT) is actively engaged with travelers to ensure they have information they need and are following the CDC guidelines. The Port of Baltimore is also engaged in similar screening protocols.

Title/Description: Continuity of Operations (COOP) management
Comments: All state agencies have reviewed their Continuity of Operations (COOP) plans and submitted them to the Maryland Emergency Management Agency.

Title/Description: State of Emergency
Comments: Done in order to coordinate response after coronavirus after confirming cases in Maryland.

Title/Description: Bulletin
Comments: For health carriers regarding coverage for COVID-19 prevention, diagnosis, and treatment.

Title/Description: Emergency Legislation.
Comments: Allowing his state to access rainy day funds, and formed a Coronavirus Response Team to advise on health and emergency management decisions.

Title/Description: State employee travel restrictions
Comments: Governor Hogan suspeded all business-related out-of-state travel for state employees.

Title/Description: Enacted recommendations and additional actions
Comments: The Department of Motor Vehicles moved toward an all appointment system for all transactions, to reduce walk-in visits and foot traffic.

Title/Description: Enacted recommendations and additional actions
Comments: The Maryland Health Benefits Exchange established a special enrollment period through Maryland Health Connection for COVID-19.

Title/Description: Enacted recommendations and additional actions
Comments: The Department of Corrections and Public Safety Services discontinued visitation services for an individual in infirmaries.

Title/Description: Enacted recommendations and additional actions
Comments: For long-term care communities, access is restricted to essential visits only; staff are prohibited from international travel; and it is recommended that facilities screen all individuals entering the facilities.

Title/Description: Enacted recommendations and additional actions
Comments: All state veterans’ facilities are required to follow state-issued guidelines for long-term care facilities.

Title/Description: Maryland Emergency Management Agency moving to its highest action level.
Activates the National Guard.
Remote work
Comments: All state government is raised to “elevated level two” and all non-essential state employees who are approved for telework will be required to do so.

Title/Description: School closures
Comments: Closing all public schools from March 16 through March 27.

Title/Description: Emergency order
Comments: Closing all casinos, racetracks, and betting facilities.

Title/Description: Assistance by the Maryland Department of Commerce and Labor
Comments: In order to support closed gambling business, the Maryland Department of Commerce and Labor compiled resources for employer and worker assistance, financial assistance, and licensing and permitting to help support the industry.

Title/Description: Restaurant and bar closure.
Gathering limitaions
Comments: Governor banned mass gatherings of over 50 people.

Title/Description: Omnibus Health Care Order
Comments: Increases hospital bed capacity by 60,000

Title/Description: Omnibus Health Care Order
Comments: Activates the states medical reserve corps

Title/Description: Omnibus Health Care Order
Comments: Establishes policies and procedures for rationing, distributing and stockpiling resources received from the Strategic National Stockpile

Title/Description: Omnibus Health Care Order
Comments: Allows for interstate reciprocity of practice for any individual that holds a valid health care license

Title/Description: Omnibus Health Care Order
Comments: Allows for inactive clinicians to practice without first reinstating their inactive license

Title/Description: Omnibus Health Care Order
Comments: Allows for actions to control, restrict, and regulate the use of health care facilities in responding to a catastrophic health emergency.

Title/Description: Emergency Order
Comments: Prohibits utility shutoffs and prohibits evictions for individuals who can show documentation that their inability to pay was due to COVID-19.

Title/Description: Maryland State Troopers
Comments: The Governor and Maryland Polic Force activated the Maryland State Troopers to be deployed across the state and activated two Area Support Medical Companies (under the National Guard) to carry out emergency functions.

Title/Description: Proclamation
Comments: To postpone April 28 primary elections until June 2, while moving forward with the 7th congressional general election by implementing a vote-by-mail system.

Title/Description: Drive through centers
Comments: All vehicle emissions inspection programs will be shut down, and steps will be taken to turn these facilites into drive through testing centers.

Title/Description: Cashless Tolling
Comments: The state is moving to cashless tolling statewide in an attempt to limit interaction between the public and toll collectors.

Title/Description: Guidance
Comments: The Governor's legal cousel issued guidance on the prohibition of large gatherings, and on the closure of bars, restaurants, casinos, and other facilities.

Title/Description: Maryland Bussiness Express Coronavirus Information for Bussinesses.
Comments: Posted by the Maryland Department of Commerce.

Title/Description: Webinar for preventing the spread of coronavirus in the workplace.
Comments: The Department of Health hosted a webinar providing guidance for businesses in preventing the spread of coronavirus in the workplace.

Title/Description: Restriction on public transportation.
Comments: The Governor announced that no one should use public transportation except emergency personnel, front-line health-care workers, or those whose jobs are essential to the supply chain.

Title/Description: Spring Break travelers are quarantined.
Comments: All returning spring break travelers quarantine for the next 14 days and avoid people over the age of 60.

Title/Description: The closure of all non-essential businesses.
Small businesses and workers financial assistance.
Comments: More than $175 million to assist small businesses and workers, with $125 million in loans and grants to small businesses and nonprofits through the Maryland Small Business COVID-19 Emergency Relief Fund. Another $75 million loan fund and a $50 million grant fund, with $1 million in grants dedicated to non-profits, will provide working capital to be used for payroll, rent, fixed-debt payments and other mission critical cash operating costs

Title/Description: Financial incentive for businesses to manufacture personal protective equipment and other supplies
Comments: Maryland Commerce is also working on creating a $5 million fund to incentivize businesses to manufacture personal protective equipment and other supplies to satisfy the increasing needs of the healthcare industry.

Title/Description: COVID-19 Layoff Aversion Fund.
Comments: The Governor has allocated $5 million, and the Maryland Department of Labor has allocated $2 million, to collaboratively launch the COVID-19 Layoff Aversion Fund.

Title/Description: Future field hospital and alternative care site
Comments: The Governor toured the Baltimore Convention Center, which is to be turned into a field hospital and alternative care site with support from the Maryland National Guard.

Title/Description: Presidential disaster declaration.
The Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services approved Maryland’s request for a Section 1135 Medicaid waiver.
Comments: The approved waiver enables Maryland to provide flexibilities in Medicaid provider screening and enrollment, forgo certain pre-admission screening and annual resident review assessments, lift prior authorization requirements, allow for reimbursement facility services in alternative settings, extend fair hearing timelines, and waive public comment and tribal consultation requirements for certain changes to the Medicaid state plan.

Title/Description: Fund research into the potential therapeutic uses of COVID-19 convalescent plasma.
Comments: The Governor announced a joint partnership between the Governor’s office, Bloomberg Philanthropies and John Hopkins University to fund research into the potential therapeutic uses of COVID-19 convalescent plasma. The funding consists of a $3 million gift from Bloomberg Philanthropies, in addition to $1 million in backing from the state of Maryland.

Title/Description: Stay at Home order
Opening of four new testing sites
Updates on economic relief for workers and small businesses.
Comments: Updates on the state’s $175 million economic relief package for workers and small businesses, including an additional $2 million for the state’s COVID-19 Layoff Aversion Fund.

Title/Description: Executive Order.
Comments: Amends the previous May 20 order regarding telehealth by expanding these services beyond audio-only methods, to methods such as email.

Title/Description: Executive Order.
Comments: Ensuring that workers who provide important support services to the disabled will be treated as health care providers under the recently enacted Families First Coronavirus Response Act.

Title/Description: New directives for nursing facilities to direct all staff who interact with residents.
Comments: To wear personal protective equipment, create separate observation and isolation areas for residents, and expedite all testing through the Maryland State Public Health Laboratory.

Title/Description: New Executive Order.
Comments: Empowering local health departments to take action against any businesses, establishments, and construction sites they deem unsafe.

Title/Description: The Department of Health to immediately take all actions necessary in order to provide further demographic breakdowns on race and ethnicity for all case data.
Comments: The Governor directed the Department of Health, through the Office of Minority Health and Health Disparities. Including hospitalization rates and mortality.

Title/Description: The White House and federal officials have now designated the Baltimore-Washington corridor as an emerging hotspot.
The state is instituting a budget and hiring freeze amid estimates that Maryland is facing a projected $2.8 billion shortfall due to this public health emergency.
Comments: He also announced that he has directed the Maryland Department of Labor to take steps to bolster the state’s unemployment insurance process to handle an unprecedented surge in claims.

Title/Description: The launch of COVIDConnect.
Comments: A new registry for Marylanders who have recovered from COVID-19. This registry will serve as a community platform to share experiences and lend support to others who are coping with the recovery process.

Title/Description: The state plans to hire 1,000 people to work in local health departments as investigators work to trace the path of the coronavirus.
Face masks must be worn while inside any retail establishment.
Comments: Including grocery stores, pharmacies or convenience stores, or while riding on any public transit.

Title/Description: Maryland is now in a position to plan the gradual rollout of the state’s recovery phase.
Comments: Tenets include expanding testing capacity, increasing hospital surge capacity, ramping up supply of PPE, building a robust contact tracing operation.

Title/Description: a statement to President Trump requesting an additional $500 billion
Comments: to address revenue shortfalls.

Title/Description: the state’s roadmap to recovery will be unveiled the following week.
the successful completion of ‘Operation Enduring Friendship,’
Comments: brought 500,000 tests to Maryland as purchased through LabGenomics, a company in South Korea.

Title/Description: The Governor sent a letter to President Trump.
Comments: accepting an offer to allow the state to use federal labs for coronavirus testing and to request guidance on how to proceed.

Title/Description: barbershops and hair salons to reopen by appointment only to serve certain essential workers.
Comments: Such as military personnel and first responders.

Title/Description: Laurel Medical Center has officially reopened
The Governor also announced additional measures and updates related to his reopening plan.
Maryland Strong: Roadmap to Recovery
Comments: outline building blocks for recovery related to expanding testing capacity, increased hospital surge capacity, ramping up supply of PPE, and improving contact tracing operations.

Title/Description: Maryland Department of Health to publish data related to COVID-19 cases and fatalities.
Comments: associated with nursing homes, assisted living facilities, and other facilities providing congregate living for residents.

Title/Description: Maryland awarded more than $1.6 million in a first round of grants to 20 Maryland companies
Comments: For pivoting to or expanding production of Personal Protective Equipment.

Title/Description: An expanded testing strategy.
Comments: A multi-state, multi-agency operation to address outbreaks at poultry processing plants, and new requirements for nursing homes.

Title/Description: Maryland Manufacturing Network Supplier Portal to centralize PPE resources for buyers.
Comments: The Maryland Manufacturing Network Supplier Portal, which is the result of a partnership between the Maryland Department of Commerce and the Maryland Manufacturing Extension Partnership

Title/Description: The resumption of elective medical procedures.
The broadening of permitted outdoor activities.
The Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) approved Maryland’s second request for a Medicaid 1135 waiver.
Comments: The waiver allows Maryland to waive consent requirements for Home and Community-Based Services (HCBS),to allow for HCBS in additional settings, and to reimburse for personal care provided by legally responsible individuals, including family caregivers

Title/Description: The beginning of Stage One of the ‘Maryland Strong: Roadmap to Recovery’.
Comments: Moving from a Stay at Home order to a Safer at Home public health advisory.

Title/Description: The beginning of Stage One of the ‘Maryland Strong: Roadmap to Recovery’.
Comments: The gradual reopenings of retail, manufacturing, houses of worship, and some personal services.

Title/Description: The launch of the Caregiver Services Corps.
Comments: A program to support Maryland seniors who have been affected by the pandemic. The program will deploy volunteers and other resources to the homes of seniors who need urgent assistance with everyday tasks when their typical caregiver becomes unable to help.

Title/Description: The state has reached a critical milestone in its long-term COVID-19 testing strategy.
Comments: Surpassing 200,000 tests and completing testing of 3.5 percent of the state’s population, and now has the capacity and supplies to offer testing to Marylanders who may have been exposed to the disease even if they do not have symptoms.

Title/Description: Maryland will begin universal COVID-19 testing at all state-run correctional and juvenile facilities.
Comments: As part of the state’s long-term testing strategy.

Title/Description: The state is delivering more than 20,000 tests per week to nursing homes.
The state’s Public Health Laboratory is producing up to 10,000 tubes of viral transport media on a weekly basis.
Comments: To overcome supply chain challenges.

Title/Description: Boost testing resources.
The state is distributing more than 33,000 additional swabs to local jurisdictions to help boost local testing capacity.
Adventist HealthCare Fort Washington Medical Center became the first hospital in the nation to install STAAT Mod TM.
Comments: STAAT Mod TM (Strategic, Temporary, Acuity-Adaptable Treatment) modular units to care for COVID-19 and other critically ill patients.

Title/Description: A new free testing site at Six Flags America.
Comments: On May 29.

Title/Description: The State of Maryland can now safely move forward with the completion of Stage One of the ‘Maryland Strong: Roadmap to Recovery,’
Comments: Due to successful Stage One reopenings across the state and improvements in key data and metrics. Stage One of the ‘Maryland Strong: Roadmap to Recovery,’ includes the resumption of outdoor dining and outdoor activities such as youth sports and youth day camps, and the reopening of outdoor pools and drive-in movie theaters.

Title/Description: Two additional COVID-19 emergency orders.
Comments: Extending a prohibition on utility shutoffs and residential late fees, and allowing breweries, wineries, and distilleries to provide service in outdoor seating areas.

Title/Description: Maryland’s COVID-19 positivity rate has dropped to 10.9%.
Comments: Current total hospitalizations have fallen to their lowest level since April 15.

Title/Description: Maryland’s COVID-19 positivity rate has dropped to 9.5%—below 10%.
Comments: For the first time since late March—and total current hospitalizations have fallen to their lowest level since April 14.

Title/Description: Maryland will begin to move into Stage Two of the ‘Maryland Strong: Roadmap to Recovery,’.
Comments: With a safe and gradual reopening of workplaces and businesses, along with additional personal services.

Title/Description: Additional safe and phased reopenings through Stage Two of the ‘Maryland Strong: Roadmap to Recovery’.
Comments: Such as reopening indoor dining and outdoor amusement parks.

Title/Description: Key health metrics continue to trend in a positive direction, with the positivity rate dropping to 6.55%.
Comments: Positivity rates now in single digits in all 24 jurisdictions and ICU bed metrics falling below 300 for the first time since April 6.

Title/Description: The Department of Health will begin operating a free COVID-19 testing site at the Baltimore Convention Center.
A supplemental appropriations bill.
Comments: Filed by Governor Baker would allow the Massachusetts Department of Public Health to use surplus funds in unrelated accounts in the event of unanticipated costs related to communicable diseases. The Massachusetts House and Senate have approved mid-year spending bills based on the Governor’s request, which must be reconciled.

Title/Description: Incident Command Structure
Comments: The Massachusetts Department of Public Health established an Incident Command Structure to facilitate regular dissemination of information from federal and state partners to statewide stakeholders.

Title/Description: Precautionary measures
Comments: Governor Baker announced that due to the emergency health situation, the state is urging colleges and universities to cancel upcoming organized international trips.

Title/Description: State of emergency
Travel restrictions for many state employees.
$15 million dollar spending bill
Comments: Will cover costs of monitoring, treating, containing and educating the public about COVID-19.

Title/Description: Allowance of Massachusetts license for medical professionals
Comments: Medical proferssional from other states are allowed to obtain a Massachusetts license in 24 hours.

Title/Description: Restriction on public gatherings.
Comments: Governor Baker bans all gatherings of 250 people or more.

Title/Description: School closure preparation.
Comments: All public and private elementary and secondary schools will be closed for three weeks.

Title/Description: Public gathering restiction
Comments: Gatherings of more than 25 people are prohibited.

Title/Description: Caring facility restrictions
Comments: Visitors are prohibited from entering long-term care facilities and nursing homes.

Title/Description: Unemployment assistance.
Comments: The administration is filing emergency legislation that will allow new claims to be paid more quickly by waiving the one week waiting period for unemployment benefits.

Title/Description: Legislative package
Comments: Aimed at supporting municipal governance that allows changes to the postponing of town meetings, adopting lower quorum rules, permitting municipal spending of revolving funds, and other measures.

Title/Description: Small Bussiness Recovery Loan Fund
Comments: $10 million dollars that aims to provide emergency capital (up to $75,000) to businesses in the state impacted by COVID-19.

Title/Description: Emergency Order
Comments: Licensed physicians who have retired in the last year, and who are in good standing, may be reactivated for a period of 90 days after the end of the public health emergency.

Title/Description: Emergency Order
Comments: Providers in good standing from other states can obtain emergency licenses to practice in the state, or practice through telemedicine

Title/Description: Emergency Order
Comments: The ability of residents to provide critical services (under supervision) will be expanded.

Title/Description: Emergency Order
Comments: Allows licenses for nurses, pharmacists and physician assistants, who would otherwise be up for renewal, to extend their licensure status by 90 days after the end of the public health emergency.

Title/Description: Emergency Order
Comments: Adjusts the minimum standards for ambulance staffing to ensure capacity of EMS services.

Title/Description: Emergency Order
Comments: Expands telehealth by facilitating those services across state lines.

Title/Description: Initial Emergency Fund
Comments: The Governor's administration is distrubuting $5 million dollars to address needs of community health boards. Additional funding will support public health emergency resources in cities and towns.

Title/Description: Request Governor's Emergency Loan Fund
Comments: Formal request that the Small Business Administration issue a declaration of economic injury so as to expedite the ability for small business to obtain loans.

Title/Description: Closure of all early education and childcare centers.
Comments: They are to close on March 23, 2020.

Title/Description: Senate S25.99
Comments: Authorizing unemployment assistance to workers impacted by COVID-19. The legislation will allow for new claims to be paid in an expedited fashion by waiving the one week waiting period for such benefits.

Title/Description: Low interest federal disaster loans
Comments: the U.S. Small Business Administration will offer low-interest federal disaster loans for working capital to Massachusetts small businesses suffering substantial economic injury.

Title/Description: The Massachusetts National Guard
Comments: Will contian up to 2,000 members who will support requests from state agencies for equipment, logistics, warehousing, and related duties.

Title/Description: Emergency order.
Comments: Requiring all businesses and organization who are not proving “COVID-19 Essential Services” to close their physical workplaces and facilities. Simultaneously, the Governor also stated that he is limiting mass gathering to 10 people or less. The order does not however prohibit gatherings of more than 10 people in an outdoor space.

Title/Description: Act to Further Address Challenges Faced by Municipalities and School Districts
Comments: Resulting from COVID-19, which would provide administrative relief to state and local government entities in the form of modifying local permitting processes, enabling municipalities to extend tax and finance deadlines, and extending deadlines for certain education requirements.

Title/Description: Launch of a new text-based notification system.
Comments: To deliver important information about the Commonwealth’s COVID-19 response to Massachusetts residents.

Title/Description: New actions across the commonwealth.
Comments: Include extending the closure of all public and private schools and non-emergency child care programs and actions to protect homeowners and low-income tenants from eviction and foreclosure.

Title/Description: Creation of a COVID-19 Advisory Board.
Comments: Includes a group of medical experts that will support the Response Command Center and actions across the commonwealth.

Title/Description: The Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services approved Massachusetts’ request for a Section 1135 Medicaid waiver.
Comments: The approved waiver enables Massachusetts to provide flexibilities in Medicaid provider screening and enrollment, forgo certain pre-admission screening and annual resident review assessments, lift prior authorization requirements, allow for reimbursement facility services in alternative settings, extend fair hearing timelines, and waive public comment and tribal consultation requirements for certain changes to the Medicaid state plan.

Title/Description: Extension the 2019 state individual income tax filing and payment deadline.
Comments: The Governor announced that he extended the 2019 state individual income tax filing and payment deadline from April 15 to July 15.

Title/Description: Issuing guidelines on travel and transportation
Comments: Travelers arriving to Massachusetts are instructed to self-quarantine for 14 days.

Title/Description: Offering support for health care professionals and patients.
Comments: State medical schools will facilitate early graduation of their qualified fourth-year students to allow graduates to support the health care workforce.

Title/Description: Offering support for health care professionals and patients.
Comments: The Board of Registration in Medicine will provide medical school graduates who have matched as an intern, resident or fellow with a Board-approved Massachusetts health care facility or training program with Emergency 90-Day Limited Licenses to practice medicine.

Title/Description: Offering support for health care professionals and patients.
Comments: The launch of Buoy Health’s new online resource for residents to check their symptoms and connect with the next appropriate health care resource.

Title/Description: Offering support for health care professionals and patients.
Comments: A public health order to provide Advanced Practice Registered Nurses, in good standing, with greater flexibility in their prescribing practices.

Title/Description: Match volunteers with communities and health care providers.
Comments: Partnership with the Massachusetts Medical Society to match volunteers with communities and health care providers based on skillsets and need.

Title/Description: New online portal.
Comments: Individuals and companies can easily donate or sell personal protective equipment and sign up to volunteer to support COVID-19 emergency response efforts.

Title/Description: Support efforts to expand the Commonwealth’s health care workforce.
Comments: Including expediting licensing for certain health care workers and onboarding for health care volunteers who have signed up through the Administration’s new online volunteer portal.

Title/Description: Certain MassHealth regulations regarding the transfers and discharge of long-term facility residents be waived.
Comments: For the purposes of moving residents to designated COVID-19 facilities.

Title/Description: Updates to the list of businesses deemed to provide “COVID-19 Essential Services”.
Extended the non-essential business emergency order to May 4.
Emergency order.
Comments: Requiring all coastal beach reservation parking areas managed by the Department of Conservation and Recreation to close.

Title/Description: Outlined projections related to the anticipated surge of COVID-19 cases in the Commonwealth.
Comments: Outlined by the Governor’s Administration, through the Response Command Center.

Title/Description: An initiative that will focus on tracing the contacts of confirmed positive COVID-19 patients, supporting individuals in quarantine, and leverage public health college students to augment the contact tracing being done.
Comments: Builds on the efforts already underway from the Command Center to leverage public health college students to augment the contact tracing being done by local boards of health.

Title/Description: The launch of a new rapid testing site with the capability of testing 1,000 people a day
Comments: As well as, same day results.

Title/Description: A new financial package to support providers through the MassHealth program.
Comments: By providing $800 million crisis stabilization funding to support health care providers impacted by and responding to the public health emergency, $80 million to nursing facilities, and $400 million to safety net hospitals.

Title/Description: The Governor filed legislation to provide health care workers and facilities protections from civil liability.
Comments: While they are on the front lines of response to this public health emergency.

Title/Description: An expansion of COVID-19 testing sites for public safety personnel, new Crisis Standards of Care documentation for the Commonwealth’s health care facilities, and new guidance to further promote social distancing at grocery stores.
Details for the initial implementation of federal unemployment benefits in the CARES Act.
Comments: Such as an additional $600 per week for individuals collecting benefits from regular unemployment compensation and a 13-week extension of benefits for individuals who exhausted their previous benefits.

Title/Description: The details for a new field medical station at the Boston Convention and Exhibition Center.
Increased support for health care workforce and patients.
Expansion of COVID-19 reporting data.
New guidance for workers seeking unemployment benefits.
Protections for survivors of domestic violence and sexual assault.
The Governor’s Administration provided an update on the Commonwealth’s hospital capacity.
Comments: As well as, efforts to add more beds to the system to meet the expected surge.

Title/Description: The Governor's Administration issued further public health guidance.
Comments: Included residents having to wear a mask or face covering in public and expanded access to free priority testing sites for first responders and grocery store workers.

Title/Description: A new initiative and over $10 million in funding to support manufacturers’ efforts to pivot production operations to produce personal protective equipment and other critical devices.
Comments: Such as ventilators, sanitizers, and thermometers. The Manufacturing Emergency Response Team (M-ERT) is a coordinated response by the Governor’s Administration and leading academic and industry stakeholders to support the Commonwealth’s manufacturers in their efforts to produce much-needed supplies for front-line workers and the health care system.

Title/Description: The expansion of COVID-19 response reporting to include statewide hospital capacity and PPE distribution data.
An additional $130 million in new funding to long-term care facilities, the expansion of mobile testing for these facilities, and crisis management support.
The distribution of approximately 200,000 respirator masks.
Comments: For local law enforcement and firefighters through the Massachusetts Emergency Management Agency.

Title/Description: The state’s ongoing comprehensive strategy to address homelessness during the COVID-19 pandemic.
Comments: Through the establishment of isolation and recovery sites, deployment of supplies and supporting families in emergency assistance and domestic violence shelters.

Title/Description: Residents who are not eligible for regular unemployment benefits can now apply online for the new Pandemic Unemployment Assistance program.
Comments: This includes self-employed workers, independent contractors, gig economy workers, and those with limited work history.

Title/Description: Extending the closure of all public and private schools through the end of the school year.
The closure of all non-emergency child care programs until June 29.
Further support for students and families who have been impacted.
The Division of Banks joined a multi-state initiative to secure payment relief options for Massachusetts student loan borrowers
A Consumer Advisory with information and resources for private student loan borrowers.
An initiative to expand testing at Community Health Centers
Comments: By the the Governor’s Administration.

Title/Description: New Wi-Fi hotspots.
Comments: By the the Governor’s Administration.

Title/Description: Two waiver requests with CMS.
Comments: It will give the state and its Medicaid program, MassHealth, more flexibility to respond to this public health emergency.

Title/Description: A second round of funding up to $130 million for nursing facilities.
Comments: To support response efforts over the next two months.

Title/Description: Increased funding of $44 million for residential congregate care service providers.
The administration has implemented required testing for staff and residents of nursing facilities.
The Governor extended the essential services emergency order to May 18th.
Launched a Reopening Advisory Board.
Comments: It will produce a plan to the Governor by May 18th.

Title/Description: An order requiring the use of masks or face coverings in public places.
Expanded community health center testing capacity.
The Governor highlighted the MERT initiative.
Comments: Assists local manufacturers in transitioning operations to produce personal protective equipment and other critical items.

Title/Description: The Governor provided updates on the COVID-19 Community Tracing Collaborative.
Comments: It was launched last month (April, 2020).

Title/Description: A new public awareness campaign.
Comments: In partnership with Mass League of Community Health Centers. the new public awareness campaign aims to encourage residents to continue seeking medical care.

Title/Description: The Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) approved Massachusetts’ additional request for a Medicaid 1135 waiver.
Comments: The waiver allows Massachusetts to allow for home and community-based services in additional settings.

Title/Description: A four-phase approach to reopening the Massachusetts economy.
Published Mandatory Workplace Safety Standards.
Comments: They will apply across all sectors and industries once reopening begins.

Title/Description: The Governor’s Administration filed a supplemental budget bill for Fiscal Year 2020.
Comments: It will authorize $1 billion in spending necessary to cover incurred and expected costs during the public health crisis, and it is expected that this spending will result in no net cost to the Commonwealth, after anticipated federal reimbursement and other federal funding sources.

Title/Description: The Governor toured MatTek Life Sciences.
Comments: Who is participating in the Manufacturing Emergency Response Team that assists local manufacturers in transitioning operations to produce personal protective equipment.

Title/Description: The Governor toured a new testing site.
Comments: Reminded residents of the Department of Public Health’s updated guidance about the appropriate use of laboratory testing for COVID-19 and expanded testing recommendations in clinical and commercial laboratories.

Title/Description: The Governor's Administration will submit its plan to expand testing to the federal government.
Comments: This month (May) and highlight the delivery of over 7.5 million pieces of PPE and supplies to be delivered to front-line workers throughout the Commonwealth.

Title/Description: The Governor's Administration is preparing to distribute up to $502 million from the federal Coronavirus Relief Fund.
Comments: To local cities and towns.

Title/Description: The Governor released a partial list of employers who are committing to continuing work from home policies for the foreseeable future.
Comments: As a way to provide more flexibility for their employees and greater capacity for social distancing on the state’s public transportation system.

Title/Description: The Governor released, "Reopening Massachusetts", the Reopening Advisory Board’s report.
Comments: Details a four-phased strategy to responsibly reopen businesses and activities.

Title/Description: The Governor released a new “Safer At Home” Advisory.
Comments: Instructs residents to stay at home unless engaging with newly opened activities.

Title/Description: The Governor toured Symmons Industries.
Comments: An 80-year-old Massachusetts manufacturer that has implemented the new Mandatory Workplace Safety Standards as manufacturing operations scale back up.

Title/Description: The Governor’s Reopening Advisory Board released new Sector Specific Protocols.
Comments: Describe policies, procedures and best practices that particular industries should follow to decrease the risk of transmission.

Title/Description: Massachusetts residents who are eligible for the federal CARES Act and qualify for having exhausted their regular unemployment compensation may now receive the new Pandemic Emergency Unemployment Compensation.
Comments: Provides up to 13 additional weeks of benefits.

Title/Description: Executive Order.
Comments: Provides a detailed list of businesses and activities that fall into Phases II, III, and IV of the Commonwealth’s Re-Opening Plan.

Title/Description: Phase II of the Commonwealth’s reopening plan will begin on June 8.
The Governor filed “An Act to Ensure the Collection of COVID-19 Data”.
Comments: This will build on legislation recently signed by the governor to expand data collection during the pandemic.

Title/Description: The Governor signed “An Act Addressing COVID-19 Data Collection and Disparities in Treatment”.
Comments: Will allow for the collection and publication of additional data to understand the impact of COVID-19 on underserved and underrepresented populations and other groups.

Title/Description: The availability of pop-up testing sites throughout the Commonwealth for individuals who have recently participated in large gatherings.
Additional administrative tax relief measures for businesses.
Comments: Such as the postponing the collection of regular sales tax, meals tax, and room occupancy taxes for small businesses, as well as waiving all penalties and interest that would otherwise apply.

Title/Description: Step Two of Phase II of the Commonwealth’s four-phase reopening plan, Reopening Massachusetts, will begin on June 22.
A $275 million COVID-19 economic recovery package to generate economic growth.
Comments: It additionally proposes to amend the scope of several proposed programs, to target funding towards specific communities including those hardest hit, reallocate funding among proposed authorizations to better address the significant economic impacts, and establish new tools to promote equity and drive economic growth in communities and among businesses facing barriers to entry.

Title/Description: The Governor  highlighted an innovative partnership to help provide Boston’s most vulnerable residents with access to food by utilizing RIDE paratransit services.
Comments: Due to the food insecurity concerns caused by the pandemic.

Title/Description: The Michigan Department of Health and Human Services activated its Community Health Coordination Center (CHECC)
Emergency Operations Center
Comments: Governor Whitmer activated the state Emergency Operations Center to coordinate with state, local and federal agencies to help prevent the spread of COVID-19.

Title/Description: Four task forces
Comments: Created to combat the spread of coronavirus and assess the impact it may have on Michiganders’ day-to-day lives.

Title/Description: State of Emergency
School closures.
Comments: All schools closed until April 6, 2020.

Title/Description: Executive Order 2020- 8.
Comments: Effective until April 13, 2020, which imposes enhanced restrictions on price gouging of goods, materials, emergency supplies, and consumer food items.

Title/Description: Guidance on limitations of mass gatherings.
Comments: Limits mass gatherings of more than 50 people.

Title/Description: Executive order: 2020- 9
Comments: Orders the temporary closure of bars, casinos and theatres, and limits restaurants to only serve carry-out and delivery orders.

Title/Description: Executive order: 2020- 10
Comments: Orders the temporary expansion of eligibility for unemployment benefits.

Title/Description: Executive order: 2020- 11
Comments: Orders a temporary prohibition on large gatherings and temporary closure of elementary and secondary schools.

Title/Description: Executive order: 2020- 12
Comments: Orders the lifting of weight restrictions for vehicles carrying and delivering necessary items, such as medical supplies, testing and treatment equipment needed to respond to COVID-19 outbreaks in the state.

Title/Description: Executive order: 2020- 13
Comments: Temporarily lifts regulatory requirements on hospitals and other care facilities in an effort to expand the number of health care providers able to respond to community needs.

Title/Description: The state National Guard supports its Department of Health and Human Services
Comments: Gathers critical personal protective gear like gloves, gowns, and face shields.

Title/Description: Executive order: 2020- 14
Comments: Extending the deadline for residents to pay back taxes, as well as avoid foreclosure on their property.

Title/Description: Executive order: 2020- 15
Comments: States that public bodies (such as boards, committees, councils, etc.) subject to the Open Meetings Act can use telephonic methods to continue meeting and conducting business.

Title/Description: Federal funding request to support the Michigan National Guard
Small Business Administration (SBA) approved her request for a statewide Economic Injury Disaster Loan declaration
Comments: Allowing small businesses to access loans from the SBA.

Title/Description: Executive Order 2020- 16
Comments: Expands child care access during the public health emergency.

Title/Description: Executive Order 2020- 17
Comments: Imposes temporary restrictions on non-essential medical and dental procedures

Title/Description: Executive Order 2020- 18
Comments: Includes minor clarifications of her executive order that temporarily imposed enhanced restrictions on the excessive pricing of goods, materials, emergency supplies, and consumer food items.

Title/Description: Executive Order 2020- 19
Comments: Allows tenants and mobile homeowners to remain in their homes during the pandemic even if they are unable to stay current on their rent. The order also relieves courts from certain statutory restrictions to enable them to postpone eviction-related proceedings until after the public health emergency has passed.

Title/Description: Executive Order 2020- 20
Comments: Makes clear that all facilities that provide non-essential personal care services must temporarily close.

Title/Description: Executive Order 2020- 21
Comments: Directing all Michigan businesses and operations to temporarily suspend in-person operations that are not necessary to sustain or protect life.

Title/Description: Financial support for small businesses.
Comments: The Michigan Economic Development Corporation will provide up to $20 million in support for small businesses through the Michigan Small Business Relief program. The funding is divided between $10 million in small business loans to support businesses facing drastic reductions in cash flow and $10 million in small business grants. The grant funding will go to local or nonprofit economic development organizations to provide grants up to $10,000 to support small businesses that have realized a significant financial hardship as a result of COVID-19.

Title/Description: Residents and businesses to donate essential medical supplies and personal protective equipment to hospitals.
Executive Order 2020- 22
Comments: Extends the deadline to complete the canvass of the March 10 primary to April 24.

Title/Description: Request for a Major Disaster Declaration.
Executive Order 2020-26
Comments: Pushes all April 2020 state and city income tax filing deadlines in Michigan to July 2020.

Title/Description: Executive Order 2020-27
Comments: Encouraging residents to vote absentee by allowing the Department of State to assist local jurisdictions in mailing absentee ballot applications to every registered voter, and to provide absentee ballots directly to new registrants.

Title/Description: State’s request for a Major Disaster declaration approved by the President.
Comments: Funding was approved for the Crisis Counseling Program and for Emergency Protective Measures from the Public Assistance Category.

Title/Description: The launch of a new volunteer website.
Comments: Where trained medical professionals can register to serve their fellow residents by assisting hospitals in responding to this public health emergency.

Title/Description: Executive Order 2020-28
Comments: Requires public water suppliers to immediately identify residences in their service area that do not currently have water service, and to make best efforts to restore service to homes where the service has been disconnected due to non-payment or damaged infrastructure. A $2-million Water Restart Grant Program will help communities comply with the order.

Title/Description: Executive Order 2020-29
Comments: Protects vulnerable populations in Michigan’s county jails, local lockups and juvenile detention centers. The order also temporarily suspends transfers into and from DOC facilities until risk-reduction protocols are adequately in place, suspends provisions of the Jail Overcrowding Emergency Act to allow local officials more flexibility in releasing vulnerable populations who do not pose a threat to public safety, and orders the State Budget Office to immediately seek a legislative transfer so that jails may be reimbursed for lodging prisoners who would have been transferred to DOC.

Title/Description: President has granted Governor's request for a formal Mission Assignment.
Comments: To allocate and order up to 3,000 members of the Michigan Army and Air National Guard for up to 90 days to perform humanitarian missions across the state.

Title/Description: Executive Directive 2020-3
Comments: Temporarily restricts discretionary spending by state departments and agencies.

Title/Description: Executive Directive 2020-4
Comments: Temporarily suspends the hiring, creating new positions, filling vacant positions, transfers, and promotions within the executive branch of state government.

Title/Description: Joint statement on the signing of two supplemental budget bills.
