Title/Description: Gatherings larger than 500 should be cancelled or postponed
NYC, Westchester, Suffolk, and Nassau Public Schools are closed for 2 weeks
Comments: Governer Cuomo announced this, to begin on March 16th

Title/Description: Executive order
Comments: Increases lospital capacity in the state; directs all nonessential state workers to work from home; opens drive-through mobile testing facilities in State Island, and Rockland County; waives all park fees in state, local, and county parks

Title/Description: Executive order delaying village elections until April 28th primary election
Executive order to close all schools March 19 - April 1
Collaborative effort from Connecticut, New York, and New Jersey
Legislation to guarantee job protection and pay for those quarantined
Legislation to guarantee comprehensive paid sick leave
Temporary halt to collection of medical and student debt
Comments: For at least 30 days

Title/Description: US Navy Ship "Comfort" deployed to New York harbor
Comments: "Comfort" is a 1000-bed hospital ship will be deployed

Title/Description: All non-essential businesses to implement work from home policies
Comments: With exceptions for specific essential services determined by the state

Title/Description: Pennsylvania to join Tri-State Collaboration
Limit social and recreational gatherings to 50 people
Comments: Tri-State Collaboration

Title/Description: Closing restaurants and bars for on-premise services
Comments: Tri-State Collaboration

Title/Description: Closing of movie theaters, gyms, and casinos
Comments: Tri-State Collaboration

Title/Description: Executive order requiring decrease in-office workforce by 75%
Comments: Exceptions for essential business

Title/Description: Deparment of Financial Services issued 90-day mortgage relief
Comments: Governor Cuomo announced the DOFS issued the directive for all New Yorkers

Title/Description: Online portal for retired health care professionals to enlist as reserve medical staff
Waived the one-week waiting requirement for accessing Unemployment Insurance
Closure of barber shops, nail and hair salons, and other care services
Guidance on PAUSE executive order
Comments: A ten-point policy to assured uniform safety for everyone, signed on Friday Mar 20th

Title/Description: Executive order to suspend and modify laws related to the disaster emergency
Comments: Executive order 202.9

Title/Description: Army Corps of Engineers to repourpose four temp hospital sites
Drug trials and aquiring them
Comments: Hydroxychloroquine, Zithromax, and chloroquine

Title/Description: All hospitals must develop plans to expand capacity
Suspend non-critical surgeries
Statement on Third Supplemental Package
Comments: Package that passed the Senate on March 26

Title/Description: State announced it recieved significant donations
Comments: From several major coroporations, philanthropic orgs, and celebrities to help increase the supply of medical materials

Title/Description: Medicaid Waiver
Comments: NY provides flexibilities in Medicaid provider screening and enrollment

Title/Description: Executive order to suspend and modify laws
Comments: EO 202.11; laws related to disaster emergency

Title/Description: Executive order to move presidential primary
Comments: From April 28 to June 23; EO 202.12

Title/Description: Executive order to extend tax filing deadline
Comments: EO 292.11; Tax filing deadline pushed to July 15 for personal and corporate taxes

Title/Description: State Dept of Health Wadsworth Lab working with other labs
Comments: To evaluate antibody testing

Title/Description: 1000 bed temporary hospital set to open
Comments: At Jacob K. Javits Convention Center on expected to open March 30, one week after construction started

Title/Description: Additional sites add emergency beds
Comments: South Beach Psychiatric Center, Westchester Square, and Health Alliance will add 695 more emergency beds

Title/Description: $7.5 million in business conseling approved
Comments: To 70 non-profit partners across the state by the Empire State Development Board of Directors

Title/Description: Mobile testing site in Northeast Bronx
Comments: No walk-ins allowed, patients must be in a vehicle

Title/Description: Executive order to continue suspension and modification of laws
Comments: EO 202.13; life insurance grace period, school to pay for childcare services, elections pushed to at least June 1

Title/Description: Public and private healtcare systems to create command center to share information
Comments: Mainly about the supplies each hospital has in stock, and what each hospital is ordering

Title/Description: Published unemployment insurace flow chart
Comments: To clearly outline how different eligible individuals can access unemployment compensation

Title/Description: Governor publicly asked US healthcare workers across the US to come to NY
Formation of the Central Coordinating Team
Comments: A hospital network to: organize upstate and downstate staffing; Assist Elmhurst hospital and other stressed hospitals; Establish patient thresholds for hospitals; Organize patient transfers to other hospitals and the USNS Comfort; Coordinate State-City stockpiles; Facilitate staffing recruitment

Title/Description: Regeneron Pharmaceuticals manufacturing 500,000 test kits
Comments: At no charge; as well as 25,000 kits per day; Apple donating 1.9 million masks; and Corning donating 100,000 tubes and provided and 500,000 tubes at reduced cost and expedited delivery

Title/Description: NYC playgrounds closed
Comments: due to lack of compliance to social distancing protocols

Title/Description: Launch of PSA to provide info on unemployment
Comments: To assure that even if employment iling is delayed, they will still receive full enemployment benefits

Title/Description: Approved Northwell's protocol to convert BiPAP machines to ventilators
Comments: by the state Department of Health

Title/Description: Conducting nightly survey of all hospital medical materials
Comments: Hospital-by-hospital survey on a nightly basis

Title/Description: 21,000 out of state volunteers to work in hospital system
Consumers/businesses may defer paying premiums
Comments: those who are experiencing financial hardship due to the pandemic. Avoid premiums under individual and small group health insurance policies

Title/Description: Javits Center to accept COVID positive patients
Comments: a 2500 emergency medical facility being operated by the U.S. Army

Title/Description: Executive order to redistribute ventilators and PPE
Comments: from institutions that don't currently need them

Title/Description: Website launched providing comprehensive virus testing data
Comments: updated daily with latest data

Title/Description: Federal govt deploying 1000 personell to NY
Comments: Doctors, nurses, respitory technicians, and therapists

Title/Description: Extending NYS on Pause functions
Comments: through April 29. After which the state will reevaluate

Title/Description: Allowing the USNS Comfort hospital shop to be used for COVID19 patients
Partnering with Headspace to offer free meditation and mindfulness
Comments: as a mental health resource for New Yorkers

Title/Description: 802 ventilators have been distributed downstate
Comments: through the "Surge and Flex" system of working together to share medical supplies

Title/Description: Creating the First Responders Fund
Comments: to assist health care workers and first responders with expenses and costs, including child care

Title/Description: Executive Order
Comments: allow state to redistribute ventilators and PPE to hospitals with highest need, extended NYS Pause functions for additional 2 weeks until 4/29, allows med schools that are slated to graduate to begin praciticing immediately to assist with the state's surge healthcare force

Title/Description: State will invest in private companies to bring rapid COVID-19 testing to scale and accelerate testing capacity
Governor sent a letter to New York’s Congressional Delegation outlining the state’s needs in the next federal relief package

Governor announced an agreement with the largest student loan servicers in New York to secure relief for student loan borrowers, a category of individuals that are not eligible for loan relief under the CARES Act

Governor launched a multi-platform, multi-language education and awareness campaign to emphasize the state’s core message to stay at home and will expand outreach and awareness to wider audiences, including hard-to-reach communities
Governor announced several actions as part of the state’s ongoing response efforts
Comments: Partnering with SUNY Albany to increase testing in minority communities and determine why more people in minority and low-income communities have higher rates of infection;  directing the State Department of Labor to make $600 in additionally weekly unemployment benefits available to all New Yorkers; Acquiring 2,400 BiPAP machines through a generous donation by Mercury Medical; and, Partnering with Delta, JetBlue and United to offer free travel to New York for medical workers to serve as part of the state’s surge healthcare force.

Title/Description: Governor announced five testing facilities downstate in primarily minority communities, bringing the state’s total number of testing facilities to nine

Governor announced the “New York Loves” initiative to coordinate all foundations, philanthropies, non-profits, charities and other entities that want to donate resources to assist local government response efforts
Governor appealed to all New Yorkers who have recovered from COVID-19 to contact the state and donate blood plasma, which has antibodies against the virus and could assist with treatment development.
Governor issued an executive order continuing the temporary suspension and modification of laws
Governor announced  the state is ramping up antibody testing through a collaborative effort with Connecticut and New Jersey to create a regional testing partnership.
Governor announced an additional $200 million in emergency food assistance will be available for more than 700,000 low-income households enrolled in the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program
Governor announced new partnerships with the private sector to provide housing for frontline medical workers
Governor announced a partnership with the New York State Court System to create a pro bono network of volunteer lawyers
Governor issued a letter calling on the U.S. Treasury to ensure New Yorkers do not have their stimulus payments frozen by banks or seized by creditors, a practice known as garnishment.
Governor joined Maryland Governor Larry Hogan in a bipartisan effort calling for $500 billion in aid to states to offset drastic state revenue shortfalls.
Governr returned ventilators to the Pathways Nursing Home and Rehabilitation Center in Niskayuna, who donated their machines to assist hardest hit areas in the state.

Governor announced the formation of a regional coalition with New Jersey Governor Phil Murphy, Connecticut Governor Ned Lamont, Pennsylvania Governor Tom Wolf, Delaware Governor John Carney, Massachusetts Governor Charlie Baker, and Rhode Island Governor Gina Raimondo
Comments: To develop a unified regional framework to gradually lift the states’ stay at home orders while minimizing the risk of increased spread of the virus

Title/Description: Governor announced the state will begin conducting antibody tests using a finger prick method to test up to 2,000 New Yorkers per day, beginning this week with frontline health care workers and other essential workers.
Governor announced the state will provide 100 ventilators to Michigan and 50 ventilators to Maryland.

Governor issued an executive order requiring all people in New York to wear a mask or a face covering when in public and in situations where social distancing cannot be maintained, such as on public transportation

Governor announced that the State University of New York and The City University of New York are using 3D printers to produce critical personal protective equipment, such as face shields, for New York’s frontline workers
Governor announced all NYS on Pause restrictions and closures will be extended until May 15, after which the states will re-evaluate additional closure periods.
Governor announced the state will provide 100 ventilators to New Jersey, building on previous interstate sharing of medical resources with Michigan and Maryland.
Governor outlined a blueprint to unpause New York, getting people back to work and easing social distancing policies without triggering renewed spread of the virus
Comments: Four steps: 1 - continue control the rate of infection and embracing the “do no harm” principle; 2 - continuing the surge and flex strategy to ensure anyone who needs medical attention gets it, while continuing to share resources amongst states and localities; 3 - ramping up a massive testing and contact tracing operation; 4 - phasing into a “new normal.”

Title/Description: Governor issued an executive order that, among other things, allows health professionals in good standing in any province or territory of Canada to practice in New York without civil or criminal penalty related to lack of licensure.
Gov launched an awareness campaign encouraging low-income New Yorkers to claim their Economic Impact Payments under the CARES Act

Gov issued an executive order directing the Department of Health to establish a single, statewide coordinated testing prioritization process that requires all laboratories in the state (public and private) to complete COVID-19 diagnostic testing in accordance with such process.
Gov with other nation's governors called on Congress to allocate $500 billion in unrestricted to aid  to shore up budget shortfalls.
Gov called for federal coordination of the supply chain to bring testing to scale so states can satisfy the necessary preconditions to begin reopening.
Gov issued an executive order allowing any town or city clerk to officiate a wedding via teleconference.

Governor, together with New Jersey Governor Murphy and Connecticut Governor Lamont announced that marinas, boatyards and marine manufacturers will be allowed open for personal use as long as strict social distancing and sanitization protocols are followed
Gov announced the state will begin an antibody testing survey
Comments: will sample 3,000 individuals to help determine the percentage of the population that is now immune to the virus, allowing more individuals to safely return to work

Title/Description: Gov announced the state is ready to transport 400 ventilators to Massachusetts within 24 hours if necessary
Gov expanded the April 18 executive order to allow any authorized officiant to perform marriage ceremonies using online video technology.

Governor, along with the governors of Connecticut, New Jersey, Massachusetts, Rhode Island, Pennsylvania and Delaware announced their appointees that will serve on the multi-state, regional council to restore the economy and get people back to work
Comments: the appointees include a health expert, an economic development expert and the respective chief of staff from each state.

Title/Description: NY State Department of Labor launched a one-stop-shop for unemployment benefits that will connect New Yorkers with benefits through a streamlined application
Gov launched a partnership with Ready Responders to bring health care services, including diagnostic testing, to residents of public housing in New York City
Gov announced the state will deliver 500,000 cloth masks and 10,000 gallons of hand sanitizer to public housing communities
Gov created the Reimagine NY Task Force, intended to improve systems in downstate New York once the state is no longer on pause
Gov announced the State University of New York will distribute more than 8,000 laptops and Chromebooks to students in need who are currently completing their spring semester coursework online

Secretary to the Governor, Melissa DeRosa, and the New York State Council on Women and Girls created a COVID-19 maternity task force to examine the best approach to authorizing and certifying additional birthing centers to provide mothers a safe alternative for low-risk pregnancies.
Comments: the task force will review literature and make recommendations on the impact of COVID-19 on pregnancy

Title/Description: Gov announced hospitals will be able to resume elective outpatient treatments on April 28th if the hospital capacity is over 25 percent for the county and if there have been fewer than 10 new hospitalizations of COVID-19 patients in the county over the past 10 days

Gov announced the state will take a regional approach to reopening and will make decisions on which counties and regions to open and when to open them based on the facts and the data specific to that area
Gov announced a partnership with Vital Strategies to launch a contact tracing program in coordination with the downstate region as well as New Jersey and Connecticut

Gov announcedthat the New York State Department of Financial Services will direct insurers to provide cash flow relief to, and ease administrative burdens on, New York State hospitals in response to COVID-19
Comments: relief includes immediate payment of outstanding accounts receivables, suspension of preauthorization requirements for all hospital services, and prohibition of the retrospective review of claims

Title/Description: Gov announced that the New York Department of Health is partnering with the state Attorney General to investigate nursing homes who violate Executive Orders requiring these facilities to communicate COVID-19 test results and deaths to residents’ families

Gov announced a directive requiring nursing homes to immediately report to the Department of Health (DOH) the actions they have taken to comply with all DOH and CDC laws, regulations, directives and guidance. Facilities could be fined $10,000 per violation or potentially lose their operating license
Gov and Attorney General launched an employment portal to increase staffing through the state and expand training and technical assistance for nursing homes to use the professional staffing portal
Gov announced preliminary phase one results of the state’s antibody testing, which found that 13.9 percent of the population have COVID-19 antibodies and are immune to the virus
Gov announced an initiative to ramp up testing in African-American and Latino communities by partnering with churches and places of worship in those communities as a network or possible testing sites
Gov announced the state will provide childcare scholarships to essential workers, such as health care providers, firefighters, and grocery store employees
Gov announced the CARES funding will be used to purchase supplies for statewide childcare providers who remain open, including masks, gloves, diapers, baby wipes, baby formula and food
Gov issued an executive order that directs the New York State Board of Elections to automatically mail every New Yorker a postage-paid application for an absentee ballot
Gov announced the state expanded its testing criteria to include all first responders, health care workers and essential employees to be tested even if they aren’t symptomatic
Gov outlined a phased plan to reopen the state and re-imagine a new normal for the state starting with construction and manufacturing
Comments: Based on CDC recommendations, once a region experiences a 14-day decline in the hospitalization rate they may begin a phased re-opening

Title/Description: Gov announced the results of phase two of the state’s antibody testing survey, which found 14.9 percent of the population have COVID-19 antibodies.
Gov announced the state is opening five drive-through testing facilities in Monroe, Erie, Broome, Niagara and Oneida counties
Gov announced the state is providing $25 million from the state’s special public health emergency fund for food banks and providers most impacted by the pandemic
Gov announced the launch of Nourish New York initiative, which is intended to purchase food and products from Upstate farms and direct it to food banks across the state
Gov announced that two million bottles of NYS Clean hand sanitizer have been distributed across all counties in the state
Gov outlined additional guidelines for the phased plan to re-open New York on a regional basis
Gov announced the creation of the New York Forward Re-Opening Advisory Board to help guide the state’s re-opening strategy
Gov announced 35 counties were approved to resume elective outpatient treatments
Gov announced results of the state’s FDNY and NYPD antibody testing survey, which found 17.1 percent of FDNY officers and EMTs have antibodies and 10.5 percent of NYPD officers have antibodies
Gov announced the state is partnering with BioReference to provide antibody tests to first responders and other essential workers from the MTA, State Police, DOCCS and others
Secretary to the Governor issued a report to the Governor outlining the COVID-19 Maternity Task Force’s initial recommendations, which were accepted in full
Comments: Recommendations includedL implementing measures to diversify birthing site options and support patient choice; extending the period of time a healthy support person can accompany a mother post-delivery; mandating testing of all pregnant New Yorkers; ensuring equity in birthing options; creating an educational campaign; and, reviewing the impact of COVID-19 on pregnancy and newborns with a special emphasis on reducing racial disparities in maternal mortality.

Title/Description: Gov announced the state’s contact tracing pilot program will begin in the coming weeks, which will include a baseline of 30 contact tracers for every 100,000 individuals and will utilize additional tracers based on the projected number of cases in each region.
Gov issued an executive order delaying school board elections and budget votes statewide until June 9
Gov outlined additional guidelines for when regions can re-open. The state will monitor four core factors to determine if a region can re-open
Comments: New Infections: Based on guidelines from the CDC, regions must have at least 14 days of decline in total net hospitalizations and deaths on a 3-day rolling average; Health Care Capacity: Every region must have the health care capacity to handle a potential surge in cases; Diagnostic Testing Capacity: Each region must have the capacity to conduct 30 diagnostic tests for every 1,000 residents per month; and, Contact Tracing Capacity: Regions must have a baseline of 30 contact tracers for every 100,000 residents, and additional tracers based on the projected number of cases in the region.

Title/Description: Gov announced New York’s National Guard has made nearly 300,000 testing kits to collect samples, 60,000 of which are being sent to labs and hospitals across New York State.
Gov announced the special enrollment period through the NY State of Health Health Plan Marketplace will remain open through June 15.
Gov announced a partnership with the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation to develop a blueprint to reimagine education in the new normal.
Gov extended an executive order allowing out-of-state health care professionals to practice in New York State.
Gov announced that Schmidt Futures will help integrate New York State practices and systems to improve telehealth and broadband access
Gov outlined the results of hospitalization data that was collected from hospitals in a targeted effort to further reduce the number of new hospitalizations per day.
Comments: The state found that a majority of individuals were: not working or traveling; predominately located downstate; predominately minorities and older individuals; predominately non-essential employees; and predominately at home.

Title/Description: Gov announced that JetBlue is donating 100,000 pairs of round-trip flights for medical personnel and nurses to honor their efforts, beginning with 10,000 pairs of tickets for New York medical professionals.
Governor announced the state’s moratorium on COVID-related residential or commercial evictions will be extended for an additional 60 days until August 20.

Governor announced the state’s $25 million Nourish New York Initiative has purchased food and products from more than 2,100 New York farms and provided support to nearly 50 food banks, soup kitchens, and food pantries.

Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) approved New York’s second request for a Medicaid 1135 waiver. The waiver allows New York to waive consent requirements for Home and Community-Based Services(HCBS) and to allow for HCBS in additional settings
Governor announced the state will extend the window for victims to file otherwise time-barred cases under the Child Victims Act for an additional five months until January 14, 2021
Governor announced the composition of New York’s Reimagine Education Advisory Council
Comments: This Council will help districts reimagine schools as they prepare to reopen

Title/Description: Governor announced the State Department of Health is investigating several cases of severe illness in children and child deaths that may be related to COVID-19
Comments: State Department of Health issued an advisory about this serious inflammatory disease to inform providers of the condition, as well as to provide guidance for testing and reporting

Title/Description: Governor launched an initiative to expand access to testing in low-income communities of color

Governor announced preliminary results of the state’s antibody testing survey of more than 1,300 transit workers in the New York City region which show 14.2 percent have antibodies, compared to 19.9 percent of the general population in New York City
Governor announced the state is helping the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) develop the national criteria for identifying and responding to COVID-19 related illness in children
Governor announced the state is notifying 49 other states across the country of emerging cases of COVID-19 related illness in children

Governor announced the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) is distributing a promising treatment called Remdesivir to treat 2,9000 people at 15 hospitals and will send more doses in the coming weeks to treat 500 more patients, including children, at additional New York Hospitals

Governor issued an executive order mandating, among other things, that all nursing homes and adult care facilities test all personnel for COVID-19 two times per week and report any positive test results to the State Department of Health by the next day.

Governor announced the Finger Lakes, Southern Tier and Mohawk Valley Regions have met all seven-metrics required to begin phase one of the state’s regional phased reopening plan when the stay at home orders expire on May 15

Governor announced that certain low-risk businesses and recreational activities will be ready to reopen statewide on May 15, including landscaping and gardening; outdoor, low-risk recreational activities such as tennis; and drive-in movie theaters.

Governor announced the members of the regional control rooms that will monitor regional metrics during the reopening process, such as hospitalization rate, death rate, number of new hospitalizations, hospital bed capacity, ICU bed capacity, testing and contact tracing within its region during reopening and alert the state if the region’s metrics no longer meet the reopening guidelines and adjust the reopening plan for that region accordingly.

Governor, in a joint statement with Maryland Governor Hogan, called on Congress to focus the next stimulus bill on funding state and local governments, working families, state testing and tracing efforts and a real economic stimulus with no handouts to corporations who do not protect their workers
Governor announced the North Country has met all seven metrics required to begin phase one of the state’s regional phased reopening plan on May 15.
Governor announced the results of the state’s antibody testing survey of 2,750 members of the New York State Police show 3.1 percent of the members have COVID-19 antibodies.
Governor announced 12 more counties are now eligible to resume elective surgeries, bringing the total number of eligible counties up to 47.
Governor announced Central New York has met all seven metrics required to begin phase one of the state’s regional phased reopening on May 15.
Governor announced an initial $3 million in grants are available to businesses to manufacture emergency medical supplies and equipment.
Governor issued an executive order that, among other things, extends the stay at home order through May 28 for regions of the state that haven’t met the state’s gating criteria.

Governor, together with New Jersey Governor Murphy, Connecticut Governor Lamont, and Delaware Governor Carney, announced a multi-state agreement to reopen public and private beaches with certain restrictions in place on May 22.
Governor announced five regions will begin reopening after successfully meeting all seven-metrics required for reopening.
Governor announced horse racing tracks across the state and Watkins Glen International Racetrack will be allowed to reopen without fans as of June 1.
Governor announced Westchester and Suffolk Counties are now eligible to resume elective surgeries and ambulatory care.
Governor announced the state doubled testing capcity to reach 40,000 diagnostic tests per day
Comments: Eligibility includes: any individual who has COVID-19 symptoms; any individual who has had contact with a person known to be positive with COVID-19; any individual who is subject to a precautionary or mandatory quarantine; any individual who is employed as a health care worker, nursing home worker or first responder; any individual who would return to the workplace in phase one of the state’s reopening plan; and any essential worker who directly interacts with the public while working.

Title/Description: Governor launched a website where New Yorkers can easily find the nearest COVID-19 testing sites.
Governor announced a partnership with CVS to bring testing to more than 60 CVS pharmacies across the state. Each site has the capacity to conduct 50 or more tests per day.
Governor announced that the state has delivered over three million free bottles of NYS Clean hand sanitizer to date
Comments: Includes: more than 275,000 bottles to the Metro Transit Authority;  188,492 bottles to the New York City Housing Authority; more than 117,000 bottles to food banks; 32,512 bottles to farms via the Cornell Cooperative Extension; and 24,060 bottles to the Boards of Cooperative Educational Services.

Title/Description: Governor announced that Western New York has met all seven-metrics required to begin reopening, joining the Central New York, North Country, Finger Lakes, Southern Tier and Mohawk Valley Regions.
Governor announced that the State Department of Health granted Erie County Medical Center a waiver to restart elective procedures.
Governor announced new efforts to connect nursing home facilities with labs to increase testing in these facilities
Comments: Labs have reserved at least 35,000 tests per day to help meet new guidelines that requires adult care facilities to test all personnel twice a week

Title/Description: Governor announced the Capital Region has met all seven-metrics required to begin phase one of the state’s regional phased reopening plan starting May 20.
Governor announced Nassau County is eligible to resume elective surgeries and ambulatory care

Governor announced a collaboration with the Greater New York Hospital Association and the Healthcare Association of New York State to implement a two-week hospital visitation pilot program in 16 hospitals across the state to allow increased visitations for family members and loved ones.
Governor announced the state will allow Memorial Day ceremonies of 10 people or less, with final decisions about ceremonies being left to local governments

Governor called on the FDA to take steps now to ensure pharmaceutical corporations that produce a COVID-19 vaccine release the rights to the vaccine to provide for immediate widespread distribution to make the vaccine available to all individuals
Secretary to the Governor announced the creation of a task force to find innovative solutions to the domestic violence crisis

Governor announced the results of the state’s antibody testing survey at churches in lower-income communities and communities of color, which show 27 percent of individuals tested positive for COVID-19 antibodies, compared with 19.9 percent of New York City’s overall population
Governor announced the state will continue its partnership with Ready Responders to expand testing from 8 to 40 public housing developments across New York City
Governor announced that beginning May 21, religious gatherings of no more than 10 people will be allowed to gather statewide
Governor announced summer school will be conducted through distance learning this year to help reduce the risk of spread. Meal programs and childcare services for essential employees will continue
Governor issued an executive order continuing temporary suspension and modification of laws relating to the disaster emergency

Governor announced the launch of the $100 million New York Forward Loan Fund to provide flexible and affordable loans to help small businesses, focusing on minority and women owned small businesses that did not receive federal COVID-19 assistance
Governor announced that state and local governments will provide death benefits for frontline workers who died from COVID-19
Governor announced the winners of the Wear a Mask New York Ad Contest – “We Heart New York” and “You Can Still Smile” – with both winning videos running as public service announcements
Governor announced the Mid-Hudson Region has met all seven metrics to begin phase one of reopening
Governor announced they will meet with President Trump on May 27 in Washington D.C. to discuss infrastructure projects that need federal approval to help supercharge the economy
Governor announced the state will fast-track the construction of the new Empire Station at Penn and new LaGuardia Airport while rail ridership and air traffic is down
Governor announced the state is continuing to direct resources and focus targeted efforts on reducing the spread in lower-income and predominately minority neighborhoods in New York City
Governor issued an executive order authorizing businesses to deny entry to individuals who do not wear masks or face coverings

Governor announced a partnership with Rosie Perez and Chris Rock, who will assist New York with building communication and education on the importance of wearing a mask and social distancing and the availability of testing and healthcare in the state
Governor announced the state will distribute 1 million masks to New York City’s hardest-hit neighborhoods
Governor announced the Metropolitan Transit Authority will pilot the use of proven UV light technology to kill COVID-19 in subway cars and crew facilities
Governor announced New York City will enter Phase 1 of reopening on June 8 and that five other regions can enter Phase 2 of reopening.

Governor announced the implementation of an early warning dashboard that aggregates the state’s expansive data collection efforts for New Yorkers, government officials, and experts to monitor and review how the virus is being contained on an ongoing basis.

Governor issued an executive order authorizing business operators and building owners to use their discretion to deny admittance to individuals who fail to comply with the requirement to wear face coverings.

Governor issued an executive order lifting reductions and restrictions on the in-person workforce at non-essential businesses designated as Phase 2 industries in those regions that have been authorized to advance to Phase 2.

Governor signed into law S.8427/A.10528, a bill that establishes a COVID-19 death benefit for the families of state and local government employees that have been on the front lines of this public health emergency.
Governor announced the state will open 10 additional testing sites – one for each zip code – in New York City COVID hotspots.
Governor announced that New York dentists can reopen statewide beginning June 1.
Governor announced Western New York is expected to enter Phase 2 of reopening on June 2 and the Capital Region is expected to enter Phase 2 of reopening on June 3.
Governor announced Western New York entered phase two of reopening, with the Capital Region on track to enter phase two on June 3.
Governor announced summer camps statewide can open on June 29.

Governor issued an executive order allowing low-risk, outdoor recreational activities and business providing such activities to open in regions that have met the public health and safety metrics required for phase one.
Governor announced outdoor dining at restaurants will be permitted in phase two of reopening.
Governor announced Erie County is now eligible to resume elective surgeries and ambulatory care.
Governor announced the state is expanding COVID-19 testing criteria to include any individual who attended any of the recent protests across the state.
Governor announced the state has reached the lowest number of deaths and hospitalizations since the COVID-19 pandemic began.
Governor signed legislation banning price gouging of personal protective equipment.
Governor signed legislation extending the deadline to submit absentee ballots until the day of the election.
Governor announced outdoor, socially distanced graduations of up to 150 people will be allowed beginning June 26.
Governor announced the MTA is accelerating construction on $2 billion in capital projects during this period of reduced ridership caused by the pandemic.

Governor announced that as New York City enters phase one of reopening, the city is now eligible to resume elective surgeries and ambulatory care. He also the announced the state is opening 14 new temporary testing sites at churches located in communities particularly impacted by the pandemic.
Governor signed legislation authorizing local governments to extend the deadline for filing property tax abatements to July 15.
Governor announced Long Island will proceed to phase two of reopening on June 10.
Governor announced the Mid-Hudson Valley entered phase two of reopening.

Governor unveiled a daily testing results dashboard to complement the early warning dashboard for New Yorkers and local governments to easily track daily test results by region and county as all regions in the state are now reopening.
Governor announced the state has established 11 testing sites in hardest hit communities.
Governor announced the state delivered 500,000 masks, as well as 10,000 gallons and 100,000 2-oz. bottles of hand sanitizer to Metro North.
Governor announced the state has distributed over four million free bottles of NYS Clean hand sanitizer statewide to date.
Governor announced that five regions – Central New York, Finger Lakes, Mohawk Valley, North Country and Southern Tier – will enter phase three of reopening on June 12.
Governor announced the state is allowing localities to open public pools and playgrounds at their discretion while following state guidance beginning June 11.
Governor announced he accepted in full the recommendations by the COVID-19 Domestic Violence Task Force to reimagine New York’s approach to services for domestic violence survivors.
Governor signed legislation suspending the forfeiture of unemployment benefits during the COVID-19 state of emergency, aligning with the Executive Order issued by the Governor on May 14.
Governor signed legislation repealing criminalization of wearing a mask in public.
Governor announced low-risk sports for regions in Phase Three of reopening can begin on July 6 with up to two spectators allowed per child.
Governor announced the state is extending the special open enrollment period in the New York State of Health Plan Marketplace through July 15.
Governor reminded bars and restaurants that any violations of reopening rules and guidelines can result in the loss of that establishment’s liquor license.
Comments: Additionally, individuals can be fined for open container and social distancing violations.

Title/Description: Governor signed legislation requiring the State Department of Health to conduct a study on the health impacts of COVID-19 on minorities in New York State.
Governor announced gatherings of up to 25 people will be allowed in Phase Three of reopening, up from the limit of 10.
Governor announced Western New York has been cleared to enter Phase Three on June 16, and the Capital Region is on track to enter Phase Three on June 17
Governor issued an executive order continuing the declaration of disaster emergency in the counties of Cayuga, Jefferson, Monroe, Niagara, Orleans, Oswego, St. Lawrence, and Wayne.
Governor directed the State Department of Health to allow midwife-led birthing centers in New York for the first time.
Governor announced that New York City is on track to enter Phase Two of reopening on June 22.
Governor announced that the Mid-Hudson Valley is on track to enter Phase Three of reopening on June 23 and Long Island is on track to enter Phase Three of reopening on June 24.
Governor signed legislation prohibiting health care employers from penalizing employees for making complaints of employer violations.

Governor announced that the New York State Department of Financial Services has reached an agreement with New York’s credit reporting industry to help residents facing hardship caused by COVID-19 to avoid unjustified negative impacts on credit reports.
Governor announced New York City is cleared to enter Phase Two of reopening on June 22.
Governor announced the Yankees and Mets baseball teams will hold spring training in New York this year, while following proper health and safety protocols.
Governor announced the Mid-Hudson region is on track to enter Phase Three on June 23.
Governor announced that $65 million in federal CARES Act funding is available for childcare providers statewide through the New York Child Care Expansion Incentive program
Comments:
Funding available includes:
$20 million to assist childcare programs with reopening and expansion of capacity by providing materials to support a more socially distant model, and for supplies and activities associated with reopening and expansion. $45 million in childcare Reopening and Expansion Incentive funds to pay for 50 percent of the cost of a newly opened classroom as an incentive to open the classroom.

Title/Description: Governor, together with New Jersey Governor Phil Murphy and Connecticut Governor Ned Lamont, announced a joint incoming travel advisory that all individuals traveling from states with significant community spread of COVID-19 quarantine for a 14-day period from the time of last contact with the identified state (Alabama, Arkansas, Arizona, Florida, North Carolina, South Carolina, Texas, Utah and Washington – this list is subject to change).
Comments: This quarantine applies to any person arriving from a state with a positive test rate higher than 10 per 100,00 residents over a 7-day rolling average or a state with a 10 percent or higher positivity rate over a 7-day rolling average.

Title/Description: Governor announced that five regions – Central New York, the Finger Lakes, the Mohawk Valley, the North Country and the Southern Tier – are on track to enter Phase IV of reopening on June 26.

Governor issued an executive order requiring all travelers entering New York from a state with a positive test rate higher than 10 per 100,000 residents or higher than a 10 percent test positivity rate, over a seven day rolling average, will be required to quarantine for a period of 14 days consistent with Department of Health regulations for quarantine.
Governor announced the state will offer to assist states with high infection rates.
Governor announced the New York Department of Health’s contact tracing program has identified and is investigating two clusters related to COVID-19 in Upstate New York.
Comments: For each cluster, isolation and quarantine measures are in place for positive cases and known contacts.

Title/Description: Governor directed the State Department of Health to investigate the potential COVID-19 exposure at a high school graduation ceremony in Westchester County after an individual who had recently traveled to Florida and attended the ceremony subsequently began showing symptoms and tested positive for COVID-19.
Governor issued an executive order that makes New York employees who voluntarily travel to high-risk states after June 25 ineligible for COVID-19 paid sick leave.
Governor announced the state will decide on July 1 whether to slow down the reopening of indoor dining in New York City as part of Phase 3 of reopening.
Governor announced the state has cleared Western New York to enter Phase 4 of reopening on June 30.
Governor announced the 2020 MTV Video Music Awards will be held at the Barclays Center in Brooklyn on August 30, with limited to no audience.

Governor announced that air conditioning filters with a Minimum Efficiency Reporting Value (MERV) rating capable of filtering COVID-19 particles (approximately 0.125 microns in diameter) or similar air exchange measures will be mandatory for large mall reopenings.

Governor announced that eight additional states (California, Georgia, Iowa, Idaho, Louisiana, Mississippi, Nevada and Tennessee) meet the metrics to qualify for the travel advisory requiring individuals who have traveled to New York from those states, all of which have significant community spread, to quarantine for 14 days.
Governor directed the State Department of Health to investigate reports of potential COVID-19 exposures associated with a religious service held on June 21 in Ticonderoga, Essex County.
Governor announced the Capital Region has been cleared to enter Phase 4 of reopening on July 1.

Governor announced that the reopening of New York City indoor dining, originally part of the city’s expected entry into Phase Three on July 6, will be postponed as states across the country that previously reopened indoor dining are experiencing upticks in COVID-19 cases.
Governor announced the state will expand its testing criteria to all New Yorkers statewide.
Governor announced the state will create an enforcement department to supplement the local enforcement of COVID-19 guidance and restrictions.
Governor announced $4.3 million in federal funding is being made available to county emergency management agencies and the City of New York to support COVID-19 planning and operational readiness.

Governor announced state outdoor pools across New York will open for swimming for the July 4 weekend under the standard operating schedule of the New York State Office of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation.
Governor announced that New York City will enter Phase Three of reopening on July 6, but that indoor dining will remain closed.
Governor announced that the New York State Department of Health is finalizing guidance on the possible reopening of schools in September.
Governor announced that casinos and movie theaters will remain closed as the state government continues for best practices to emerge.
Governor announced that the New York State Fair will be cancelled this summer.
Governor announced that New York State will make industry recommendations on the use of air filtration technology to potentially eliminate the spread of COVID-19 through air conditioning systems.

Governor announced three additional states (Delaware, Kansas, and Oklahoma) meet the metrics to qualify for the travel advisory requiring individuals who have traveled to New York from those states, all of which have significant community spread, to quarantine for 14 days.
Governor announced Long Island will enter Phase 4 of reopening on July 8.
Governor announced that New York State will decide in early August whether schools will reopen in the fall.
Governor announced that all county fairs will be canceled until further notice out of an abundance of caution.

Governor announced that beginning on July 10, malls can open in regions that have entered Phase 4 of reopening if they have implemented an enhanced Heating, Ventilation and Air Conditioning (HVAC) filtration system and follow proper ventilation protocols.

Governor announced that New York State will provide 1,000 masks and 1,000 2-ounce bottles of hand sanitizer for the Fire Island COVID Destroyers – a partnership that includes GMHC and Fire Island community leaders – to distribute on Fire Island.
Formalized the Novel Coronavirus Task Force
Comments: Governor Cooper

Title/Description: Testing at the NC State Laboratory of Public Health
Comments: Coordinated through the Division of Public Health's Communicable Disease Branch

Title/Description: State of emergency
Comments: Activates the Emergency Operation Center; controls cost burdens; protects consumers from price gouging; easier to purchase necessary medical supplies

Title/Description: Recommended cancellation of gatherings over 100
Comments: Governor Cooper

Title/Description: Executive order to close all K-12 public schools
Comments: School closure for minimum of 2 weeks; also prohibits gatherings of more than 100 people

Title/Description: Request for Small Business Administration to grant disaster declaration
Comments: For business owners in the state that are facing economic losses due to COVID-19 by Governor Cooper

Title/Description: Executive Order 118 to close sit down services
Comments: Such as restaurants and bars; and makes state unemployment benefits more widely available

Title/Description: Small Business Administration granted Governor's request for disaster declaration
Comments: For small businesses to apply for a low interest disaster loan

Title/Description: Letter to President requesting approval of key waivers
Comments: to allow the state to adapt federal food and healthcare programs to better serve North Carolinians

Title/Description: Governor shared list of funding priorities
Comments: With the North Carolina Congressional Delegation to help people afford health care, childcare, and educational needs, while preparing the state for a strong economic recovery

Title/Description: Extension of the tax filing deadline to July 15th
Comments: The NC Department of Revenue announced an extension of the April 15th tax filing deadline to July 15th for individual, corporate, and franchise taxes

Title/Description: Executive order to waive restrictions
Comments: Waives restrictions to increase access to caregivers, provide flexible child care and elder care, and allow social distancing, and ensure resources through trucking services

Title/Description: Executive order to enforce tighter limit on gatherings
Comments: EO 129; to 50 people

Title/Description: Executive order to extend school closures to May 15
Comments: EO 120

Title/Description: Executive order to close some businesses
Comments: EO 120

Title/Description: Executive order to limit visitors at long-term care centers
Comments: EO 120

Title/Description: $50 million allotment for public schools
Comments: to implement remote learning, school nutrition programs, cleaning and sanatizing, acquiring progtective equipjment, and providing child care

Title/Description: Approved request for Medicaid waiver
Request for federal govt
Comments: to provide individual assistance, crisis counseling, disaster unemployment, SBA assistance, and other programs

Title/Description: $15 million to support small business and family farms
Comments: from the Golden Leaf Foundation

Title/Description: Emergency child care operations
Comments: by NC Department of Health and Human Services, requiring emergency centers to register with the state and offering bonus pay to child care teachers

Title/Description: State received a federal disaster declaration
Comments: Allows local govts, state agencies and eligible non-profits to be reimbursed for costs incurred

Title/Description: Hotline for parnets who need food for their children
Comments: direct to locate nearby meal sites

Title/Description: Stay at home order
Comments: in effect until April 29, essential businesses continue

Title/Description: First payments for 270,000 unemployment claims to be issued
Comments: within the forthcoming week

Title/Description: Executive order allowing schools and local govt to request property
Comments: EO 122; including computers, PPE State govt may not need

Title/Description: Executive order to prohibit utilities from disconnecting people
Comments: Gives customers at least six months to pay outstanding bills, and prohibits any collecting fees or interest

Title/Description: Executive order to create more flexibility in law enforment training schedules
Comments: people training for new positions can pause trainings can pause their training to isolate/self-quarantine and resume later

Title/Description: FEMA approved state's request to provide housing alternatives for those with unstable housing
Comments: Allows state to provide alternative housing (hotels, motels, dormitories) to those with unstable housing that may need to quarantine in response/are at risk for severe COVID-19 related illness; emergency non-congregate sheltering wil provide 16,500+ units of individual housing

Title/Description: Executive order to expand the pool of healthcare works and orders essential childchare services for workers responding to crisis
Executive order to strengthen social distancing requirements and streamlinging benefits for recently unemployed
Comments: requires retail stores that still operate to implement additional social distancing policies to make shopping safer for employees/customers; mandates COVID-19 guildines for nursing facilites and recommends other long-term care facilities to adopt same approach; implements changes to accelerate certain benefit payments to those who are recently unemployed

Title/Description: Governor shared the state's vision of a path forward
Comments: for eventually easing certain social distancing policies by leveraging mass testing, robust contact tracing, and epidemiologic modeling to inform decision-making

Title/Description: Gov announced that the North Carolina Department of Health and Human Services is collaborating with the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, Duke University and East Carolina University to assess changes in COVID-19 prevalence in Chatham, Pitt and Cabarrus counties
Gov announced the state has been approved for the Pandemic Electronic Benefit Transfer (P-EBT) program, to provide additional food and benefits to more than 800,000 children across the state
Gov issued an executive order extending the stay-at-home order to May 8
Gov announced the state’s plan to begin reopening the economy through a three-phased approach
Comments: Metrics of sustained leveling or decreased trajectory in COVID-like Illness (CLI) surveillance over 14 days;  sustained leveling or decreased trajectory of lab-confirmed cases over 14 days; sustained leveling or decreased trajectory in percent of tests returning positive over 14 days; and sustained leveling or decreased trajectory in hospitalizations over 14 days.

Title/Description: Gov announced that K-12 public schools will continue remote learning through the end of the 2019-2020 school year
Gov announced a partnership to equip school buses with Wi-Fi

Gov released a recommended budget plan to invest $1.4 billion in emergency funds to help North Carolina response and recovery activities, including $75 million to support testing, tracing and trends analysis and secure the personal protective equipment needed to help the state move into Phase 1 of easing restrictions
Governor and the Secretary for the North Carolina Department of Health and Human Services provided a public update on where North Carolina stands on key metrics to safely transition into Phase 1.
Gov proclaimed May 3 – 9 Hurricane Preparedness Week, emphasizing the importance of considering how COVID-19 might alter the typical preparedness process for hurricane season
Gov signed two relief bills into law: Senate Bill 704 and House Bill 1043
Comments: Relief package includes almost $1.6 billion in relief measures for critical expenditures related to public health and safety, educational needs, small business assistance, and continuity of state government operations

Title/Description: Gov signed an executive order to modify North Carolina’s Stay at Home order to transition to Phase 1 of slowly easing certain COVID-19 restrictions effective May 8
Gov announced appointments to the DRIVE Task Force, which is focused on improving equity and inclusion in education and will submit a report to the Governor with recommendations to reach that goal
Gov announced additional school buses will bring internet access to communities without it to help more North Carolina students connect to school online.

Governor announced the state’s Task Force for Emergency Repurposing of Manufacturing, established in March, has worked with over 300 North Carolina companies to produce critical medical equipment and supplies
Governor issued an executive order providing additional regulatory flexibility to ensure capacity in the state’s health care system and improve its ability to effectively respond to ongoing threats.
Governor shared an update on the state’s gating criteria, highlighting the data and trends show that the state remains stable nearly one week into Phase 1.

Governor sent a letter to the leaders of the Golden L.E.A.F. Foundation, responsible for distribution of $125 million in loans for struggling businesses, encouraging them to ensure women and minority-owned businesses receive an equitable portion of recently approved COVID-19 relief funding.
Governor announced the state will move into Safer At Home Phase 2 of reopening on May 22
Governor and the Secretary of the North Carolina Department of Health and Human Services, joined by the North Carolina Restaurant and Lodging Association (NCRLA) President, announced Count on Me NC
Comments: The resource offers free online training to help restaurants, hotels, and other businesses learn how to best protect customers and employees from COVID-19

Title/Description: Governor announced $85.4 million in federal funds provided for COVID-19 relief to counties will be disbursed this week
Governor announced the state received a $6 million federal grant to support jobs and workforce training to help address the impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic.
Governor signed an executive order to extend the prohibition of utility shut-offs and implement a moratorium on evictions.

Governor encouraged all North Carolinians to honor June 1 as a Day of Mourning to grieve the 100,000 people in America, including almost 1,000 North Carolinians, who have lost their lives to COVID-19.

Governor announced that DHHS released new guidelines which  lays out a comprehensive set of baseline health practices that public schools should follow to minimize risk of exposure to the virus, and provides recommendations of practices that schools should implement to minimize spread of COVID-19 while allowing in-person teaching to resume.
Governor proclaimed June 15 as Healthcare Heroes Day to recognize the daily sacrifices made by healthcare professionals, particularly during the COVID-19 pandemic.
North Carolina Department of Health and Human Services allocated $35 million in federal funding to local health departments to support the COVID-19 response.

Governor announced the state will remain in Safer at Home Phase 2 for three more weeks. Additionally, the Governor announced that face coverings must be worn when people are in public places as officials seek to stabilize concerning trends of increasing viral spread.

Governor signed the Education Omnibus (SB113) into law, making modifications to the 2020-2021 school calendar requirements to expand the use of remote learning days and allow modifications for single-track year-round schools, among other things.

Governor announced the expansion of Hometown Strong, an effort to forge partnerships between rural communities and state government, to expand its focus to help all 80 rural North Carolina counties respond to COVID-19 and strengthen local economies.

Governor shared that North Carolina will continue working with schools, teachers, parents, and health experts to ensure that plans for school this coming year will protect everybody, especially those at high-risk.
Online Health Survey for International Travelers
Comments: For people who traveled internationally within the past 14 days, and they recieve information about how to monitor themselves for symptoms, and what to do if they develop symptoms

Title/Description: Recommendations released for events and large gatherings
State of emergency
Closure of all K-12 Schools
Comments: March 16 - March 20th

Title/Description: Allowed K-12 School to not make up time for closures
Executive Order to close bars and restaurants on-site
Executive Order to suspend licensure requirements for health workers
Comments: Allows healthcare workers who are licensed in another state to work in North Dakota

Title/Description: Guidance for K-12 schools
Comments: To continue education through alternative delivery methods

Title/Description: Executive Order to expand unemployment eligibility
Executive Order for state agencies to identify policy that may hinder assistance
Comments: Laws, rules, and regulations that may hinder assistance

Title/Description: Executive Order to allow expired driver's licenses as valid
Comments: For those expired on or after March 1st

Title/Description: Executive Order to expand telehealth
Comments: To allow for social distancing

Title/Description: Executive Order to expand health professionals who can work
Comments: Allows medical imaging and rediation therapy professionals to the list of health professionals who can work in the state if they're licensed in another state

Title/Description: Executive Order expanding testing locations
Comments: Licensed pharmacists to administer COVID-19 tests and issue emergency refills for medications for up to a 30-day supply

Title/Description: Executive Order requesting school districts submit distancing learning plans
Comments: by March 27, and begin instruction no later than April 1

Title/Description: Department of Commerce issued resources
Comments: Resources: North Dakota Development Fund Loans, Childcare Loan Program, and Rural Growth Incentibe Program Emergency Loans

Title/Description: Executive Order extending worker's compensation coverage
Comments: to first responders and health care providers who encounter an infected person. Notably: up to 14 days of medical and wage replacement benefits during their quarantine; and provides employees who contract the virus on the job with full workers' compensation benefits just like any other compensable work injury claim

Title/Description: Approved North Dakota's request for a Section 1135 Medicaid waiver
Childcare initiative
Comments: to provide guidance on how child care providers can continue to safely serve children through modified operating practices; establish a Child Care Emergency Operating Grant to cover operating costs associated with the modified practices and to sustain vital child care services; and provide added flexibility to allow school districts to help care for children in grades K-5 whose parents are frontline workers

Title/Description: Executive Order waiving the requirement that each county must provide at least one polling location on primary election day
Comments: may conduct June 9 primary election by mail ballot only if a county chooses to do so

Title/Description: Executive Order to expand business closures
Executive Order suspending payment of unemployment taxes and interest
Comments: on all Workforce Safety and Insurance employer accounts which will allow them to focus on preserving their business operating and retain critical cash flow

Title/Description: Governer announces official request
Comments: for a major disaster declaration to support public infrastructure and facilities; mitigation grants for counties and tribal nations; assistance for individuals and households, and supplemental nutrition and transitional sheltering assistance, among other aid

Title/Description: Amended EO 2020-10.1 through May
Comments: for the limited purpose of providing childcare services to children in grades K-5 only, for K012 teachers and other healh, safety, and lifeline worker households

Title/Description: Executive Order 2020-16 suspending the open meeting requirement
Comments: when members of the governing body are attending remotely

Title/Description: Executive Order 2020-17 temp suspending deadlines for public libraries to submit state aid applications and reports
Activation of ND's Workforce Coordination Center
Comments: to connect businesses with the volunteers and workforce they need to support health care providers, industries, and agencies

Title/Description: President granted request for a major disaster declaration
Executive Order waiving the waiting period for unemployment benefits
Comments: waives the one-week waiting period

Title/Description: Amended EO 2020-06.2 extending business closures
Comments: until April 20

Title/Description: Executive Order giving school districts ability to hold elections by mail ballot
Comments: between April 1 and June 30

Title/Description: Project "Operation Drive-In" to expand COVID19 testing
Comments: testing and improve contact tracing

Title/Description: Executive Order temp suspend certain license requirements for health workers
Executive Order requiring individuals who test positive to quarantine
Comments: self-quarantine for no less than 14 days or as directed by order of the State Health Officer

Title/Description: Executive Order suspending visitation to long-term care facilities
Comments: including skilled nursing facilities and basic care facilities

Title/Description: ProudCrowd with governor launched free mobile app, Care19
Comments: more efficiently and effectively identify individuals who may have had contact with people that tested positive

Title/Description: 4 executive orders aim at shoring up pandemic impacts on school districts, agribusiness, fuel retailers and others
Comments: grant flexibility to school districts to hold mail ballot-only elections; suspend requirement that a school district conduct a written performance review for staff that have been employed for 3+ years, allow winder-grade fuel to be sold until 5/20 instead of traditional 4/1 cutoff, suspend pesticide applicator certification for the use of non-restricted disinfectants during public health emergency

Title/Description: executive order allowing for changes necessary to maintain critical operations for vulnerable youths being served in Psychiatric Residential Treatment Facilities and Qualified Residental Treatment Programs
Comments: suspends state regulations that require routine health care checks that aren't available or not urgent; allows for alternativge servies options like telehealth; allows for state background checkes while national checks are suspended

Title/Description: governor outlined finalized hospital surge plan to stress government's responsibilit to plan for worst-case scenario so the state is well-prepared
Comments: 3 tier approach; 1 - exisiting hospital capacity with current staff/supplies/equipment; 2 - (A) hospitals further increase bed capacity and stretch staff via scheduling with a surge of equipment from state medical cache as requests (B) hospitals further increase capacity with a surge of equipment/supplies/staff from the state; 3 - establishing minimial care facilities that would be used only if hospitals in the region have reached their max level of surge capacity with beds/supplies/equipment/staff that can be provided via state resources

Title/Description: Governor ameneded executive order that extends closures for an additional 10 days for businesses including recreational facilities, health clubsm and atheletic facilities among other retailers
Governor outlined a path forward to ease social distancing policies
Comments: hinges on key capabilities such as mass testing capacity, targeted case-based interventions, and adequate PPE availability for healthcare system and public

Title/Description: Gov announced that a rapid response team that tested employees on April 16 at a Grand Forks manufacturing plant confirmed an additional 88 COVID-19 cases
Comments: the outbreak was contained and all employees were directed to self-quarantine for 14 days

Title/Description: Gov outlined a plan to significantly increase testing capacity for COVID-19.
Gov announced that the CARES Act funding will help cover unemployment insurance costs that aren’t otherwise reimbursed by the federal government
Gov announced they will lift restrictions that were placed on businesses, while implementing new guidelines and standard operating procedures for businesses as they resume or continue operations
Gov released “North Dakota Smart Restart” protocols for businesses resuming or continuing operations during the COVID-19 pandemic
Gov issued an amended executive order providing additional guidance for businesses that are resuming or continuing operations under the North Dakota Smart Restart protocols

Gov issued an executive order directing schools to provide education via distance learning which will remain in effect through the end of the current school year to help slow the spread and protect students, staff, and communities
Gov announced the Red River Valley COVID-19 Task Force to address an increasing concentration of COVID-19 cases in Cass county

Governor announced the state will begin operating the Battelle Critical Care Decontamination System for PPE that allows the state to provide shipping and N95 decontamination at no charge to health care organizations, EMS agencies, public health, public safety agencies, funeral homes, dental offices, and optometry and chiropractic clinics, among others.
Governor announced North Dakota schools will be allowed to host several activities, including summer school and college admissions testing, beginning June 1
Governor announced guidelines for large gatherings, banquets, ballrooms and event venues as part of the ND Smart Restart Plan.
Governor announced an emergency rule change to allow residents of basic care facilities to keep the Economic Impact Payments provided as part of the CARES Act.

Governor announced the state will launch a smartphone application using exposure notification technology developed by Apple and Google available to public health agencies to assist with COVID-19 contact tracing.
Governor announced the state is moving to the next phase of its reopening plan
Comments: With the move from moderate to low risk level: The recommendation for capacity in bars and restaurants increases from 50 to 75 percent; The recommendation for banquets/weddings increases from 50 percent occupancy up to 250 attendees, to 75 percent occupancy up to 500 attendees; Recommended movie theater capacity increases from 20 percent to 65 percent; and, Fitness centers may consider holding classes with high inhalation/exhalation exchange with social distancing, whereas those classes were not recommended under the moderate risk level.

Title/Description: Governor signed an executive order that modifies restrictions on visitation at long-term care facilities in North Dakota during the pandemic, allowing for a phased approach to resuming visitation as outlined in the state’s Vulnerable Population Protection Plan.

North Dakota Emergency Commission voted unanimously to direct over $406 million in federal funding to the state’s COVID-19 response and recovery efforts, with the majority of the money going to support economic recovery.
Governor signed an executive order that extends the renewal date for motor vehicle registrations and driver licenses that expired on or after March 1. The new renewal date is August 31.
Governor signed an executive order restoring the work registration and search requirements for individuals seeking unemployment benefits, effective July 26.
Ohio Department of Transportation to post information
Comments: To post information from the Ohio Department of Health in all state rest areas on hand washing protocols including messages on Ohio Travel TV

Comments: Departments of Rehabilitation and Corrects and Youth Services; to protect inmates, families, and staff

Title/Description: Governor called on Ohio university leaders to urge students to get a flu shot
Governor called on Ohio university leaders to prohibit student travel to where CDC recommended
